revision.text:
{{About|proximal [[femoral fracture]]s|fractures of the [[hip bone]]|Pelvic fracture}} {{Infobox medical condition (new) | synonyms = Proximal femur fracture<ref name=Fer2018/> | image = Cdm hip fracture 343.jpg | caption = Intertrochanteric hip fracture in a 17-year-old male | pronounce = | field = | symptoms = Pain around the [[hip]] particularly with movement, shortening of the leg<ref name=AO2009/> | complications = | onset = | duration = | types = Intracapsular, extracapsular (intertrochanteric, subtrochanteric, greater trochanteric, lesser trochanteric)<ref name=Fer2018>{{cite book|last1=Ferri|first1=Fred F.|title=Ferri's Clinical Advisor 2018 E-Book: 5 Books in 1|date=2017|publisher=Elsevier Health Sciences|isbn=9780323529570|page=615|url=https://books.google.ca/books?id=wGclDwAAQBAJ&pg=PA615|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171013224646/https://books.google.ca/books?id=wGclDwAAQBAJ&pg=PA615|archivedate=13 October 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref> | causes = Trauma such as a fall<ref name=Fer2018/><ref name=AFP2003/> | risks = [[Osteoporosis]], taking many medications, alcohol use, [[metastatic cancer]]<ref name=AO2009/><ref name=Fer2018/> | diagnosis = [[radiography|X-ray]], [[Magnetic resonance imaging|MRI]], [[CT scan]], [[bone scan]]<ref name=AFP2003/><ref name=AO2009/> | differential = [[Osteoarthritis]], [[avascular necrosis of the hip]], [[hernia]], [[trochanteric bursitis]]<ref name=AFP2003/> | prevention = Improved lighting, removal of loose rugs, exercise, treatment of osteoporosis<ref name=Fer2018/> | treatment = Surgery<ref name=Fer2018/> | medication = [[Opioids]], [[nerve block]]<ref name=Fer2018/> | prognosis = ~20% one year risk of death (older people)<ref name=AFP2003/><ref name=Fer2018/> | frequency = ~15% of women at some point<ref name=Fer2018/> | deaths = }} <!-- Definition and symptoms --> A '''hip fracture''' is a [[bone fracture|break]] that occurs in the upper part of the [[femur]] (thigh bone).<ref name=AO2009>{{Cite web|url=http://orthoinfo.aaos.org/topic.cfm?topic=A00392|title=Hip Fractures|date=April 2009|website=OrthoInfo - AAOS|access-date=2017-09-27|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170629225405/http://orthoinfo.aaos.org/topic.cfm?topic=A00392|archivedate=29 June 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Symptoms may include [[hip pain|pain around the hip]] particularly with movement and shortening of the leg.<ref name=AO2009/> Usually the person cannot walk.<ref name=AFP2003/>
<!-- Cause and diagnosis --> They most often occur as a result of a fall.<ref name=AFP2003>{{cite journal|last1=Brunner|first1=LC|last2=Eshilian-Oates|first2=L|last3=Kuo|first3=TY|title=Hip fractures in adults|journal=American Family Physician|date=1 February 2003|volume=67|issue=3|pages=537–42|pmid=12588076}}</ref> Risk factors include [[osteoporosis]], taking many medications, alcohol use, and [[metastatic cancer]].<ref name=AO2009/><ref name=Fer2018/> Diagnosis is generally by [[radiography|X-ray]]s.<ref name=AO2009/> [[Magnetic resonance imaging]], a [[CT scan]], or a [[bone scan]] may occasionally be required to make the diagnosis.<ref name=AFP2003/><ref name=AO2009/>
<!-- Prevention and treatment --> Pain management may occur with [[opioids]] or a [[nerve block]].<ref name=Fer2018/><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Guay|first1=J|last2=Parker|first2=MJ|last3=Griffiths|first3=R|last4=Kopp|first4=SL|title=Peripheral Nerve Blocks for Hip Fractures: A Cochrane Review|journal=Anesthesia & Analgesia|date=May 2018|volume=126|issue=5|pages=1695–1704|doi=10.1213/ANE.0000000000002489|pmid=28991122}}</ref> If a person's health is sufficient, surgery is generally recommended within two days.<ref name=AO2009/><ref name=Fer2018/> Options for surgery may include a [[total hip replacement]] or screws.<ref name=AO2009/> Efforts to prevent [[deep vein thrombosis]] following surgery are recommended.<ref name=Fer2018/>
<!-- Epidemiology and prognosis --> About 15% of women break their hip at some point in their life.<ref name=Fer2018/> Women are more often affected than men.<ref name=Fer2018/> Hip fractures become more common with age.<ref name=Fer2018/> The risk of death in the year following a fracture is about 20% in older people.<ref name=AFP2003/><ref name=Fer2018/>
==Signs and symptoms== [[File:Heupfractuur.jpg|thumb|the affected extremity is often shortened and unnaturally, externally rotated compared to the unaffected leg]] The classic clinical presentation of a hip fracture is an elderly patient who sustained a low-energy fall and now has groin pain and is unable to bear weight.<ref name=":0" /> Pain may be referred to the supracondylar knee. On examination, the affected extremity is often shortened and unnaturally, externally rotated compared to the unaffected leg.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/959649794|title=Current medical diagnosis & treatment 2018|others=Papadakis, Maxine A.,, McPhee, Stephen J.,, Rabow, Michael W.,|isbn=9781259861482|edition=Fifty-seventh|location=New York|oclc=959649794|last1=Rabow|first1=Michael W|last2=McPhee|first2=Stephen J|last3=Papadakis|first3=Maxine A|date=2017-09-02}}</ref>
==Risk factors== Hip fracture following a fall is likely to be a [[pathologic fracture|pathological fracture]]. The most common causes of weakness in bone are: * [[Osteoporosis]]. * [[Homocysteine]], a toxic 'natural' amino acid linked to the cause of [[heart disease]]. * Other metabolic bone diseases such as [[Paget's disease of bone|Paget's disease]], [[osteomalacia]], [[osteopetrosis]] and [[osteogenesis imperfecta]]. [[Stress fracture]]s may occur in the hip region with metabolic bone disease. * Benign or malignant primary [[bone tumor]]s are rare causes of hip fractures. * [[Metastasis|Metastatic]] cancer deposits in the proximal femur may weaken the bone and cause a pathological hip fracture. * [[Osteomyelitis|Infection]] in the bone is a rare cause of hip fracture. * Smoking (associated with osteoporosis).
==Mechanism==
[[File:Hueftgelenk-gesund.jpg|thumb|X-ray of a normal hip joint.|right|200px]]
===Functional anatomy===
The [[hip joint]], an enarthrodial joint, can be described as a ball and socket joint. The femur connects at the [[acetabulum]] of the pelvis and projects laterally before angling medially and inferiorly to form the knee. Although this joint has three [[degrees of freedom]], it is still stable due to the interaction of [[ligaments]] and [[cartilage]]. The [[Acetabular labrum|labrum]] lines the circumference of the [[acetabulum]] to provide stability and shock absorption. Articular cartilage covers the concave area of [[acetabulum]], providing more stability and shock absorption. Surrounding the entire joint itself is a capsule secured by the tendon of the [[psoas muscle]] and three ligaments. The [[iliofemoral]], or Y, ligament is located anteriorly and serves to prevent hip [[hyperextension]]. The [[pubofemoral ligament]] is located anteriorly just underneath the [[iliofemoral ligament]] and serves primarily to resist [[abduction (kinesiology)|abduction]], [[extension (kinesiology)|extension]], and some [[external rotation]]. Finally the [[ischiofemoral ligament]] on the posterior side of the capsule resists [[extension (kinesiology)|extension]], [[adduction]], and [[internal rotation]]. When considering the biomechanics of [[hip fractures]], it is important to examine the mechanical loads the hip experiences during low energy falls.
===Biomechanics===
The [[hip joint]] is unique in that it experiences combined mechanical loads. An axial load along the shaft of the [[femur]] results in [[compressive stress]]. Bending load at the neck of the femur causes [[tensile stress]] along the upper part of the neck and [[compressive stress]] along the lower part of the neck. While [[osteoarthritis]] and [[osteoporosis]] are associated with [[bone fracture]] as we age, these diseases are not the cause of the fracture alone. Low energy falls from standing are responsible for the majority of fractures in the elderly, but fall direction is also a key factor.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Hwang H. F. |author2=Lee H. D. |author3=Huang H. H. |author4=Chen C. Y. |author5=Lin M. R. | year = 2011 | title = Fall mechanisms, bone strength, and hip fractures in elderly men and women in Taiwan | url = | journal = Osteoporosis International | volume = 22 | issue = 8| pages = 2385–2393 | doi=10.1007/s00198-010-1446-4|pmid=20963399 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/444336477|title=Rockwood and Green's fractures in adults|date=2010|publisher=Wolters Kluwer Health/Lippincott Williams & Wilkins|others=Rockwood, Charles A., Jr., 1936-, Green, David P., Bucholz, Robert W.|isbn=9781605476773|edition=7th|location=Philadelphia, PA|oclc=444336477}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Nevitt|first=Michael C.|last2=Cummings|first2=Steven R.|last3=Study of Osteoporotic Fractures Research Group|date=1993-11-01|title=Type of Fall and Risk of Hip and Wrist Fractures: The Study of Osteoporotic Fractures|journal=Journal of the American Geriatrics Society|language=en|volume=41|issue=11|pages=1226–1234|doi=10.1111/j.1532-5415.1993.tb07307.x|issn=1532-5415|deadurl=no|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Elderly tend to fall to the side as instead of forward, and the lateral hip and strikes the ground first.<ref name=":0" /> During a sideways fall, the chances of hip fracture see a 15-fold and 12-fold increase in elderly males and females, respectively.
=== Neurological factors === Elderly individuals are also predisposed to hip fractures due to many factors that can compromise proprioception and balance, including medications, vertigo, stroke, and peripheral neuropathy.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Cumming|first=Robert G.|last2=Le Couteur|first2=David G.|date=2003|title=Benzodiazepines and risk of hip fractures in older people: a review of the evidence|journal=CNS Drugs|volume=17|issue=11|pages=825–837|issn=1172-7047|pmid=12921493|doi=10.2165/00023210-200317110-00004}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bakken|first=Marit Stordal|last2=Engeland|first2=Anders|last3=Engesæter|first3=Lars B.|last4=Ranhoff|first4=Anette Hylen|last5=Hunskaar|first5=Steinar|last6=Ruths|first6=Sabine|date=July 2013|title=Increased risk of hip fracture among older people using antidepressant drugs: data from the Norwegian Prescription Database and the Norwegian Hip Fracture Registry|journal=Age and Ageing|volume=42|issue=4|pages=514–520|doi=10.1093/ageing/aft009|issn=1468-2834|pmid=23438446}}</ref>
==Diagnosis==
=== Physical Exam === Displaced fractures of the trochanter or femoral neck will typically cause external rotation and shortening of the leg when the patient is laying supine.<ref name=":0" />
=== Imaging === Typically, radiographs are taken of the hip from the front (AP view), and side (lateral view). Frog leg views are to be avoided, as they may cause severe pain and further displace the fracture.<ref name=":0" /> In situations where a hip fracture is suspected but not obvious on x-ray, an MRI is the next test of choice. If an MRI is not available or the patient can not be placed into the scanner a CT may be used as a substitute. MRI sensitivity for radiographically occult fracture is greater than CT. Bone scan is another useful alternative however substantial drawbacks include decreased sensitivity, early false negative results, and decreased conspicuity of findings due to age related metabolic changes in the elderly.
As the patients most often require an operation, full pre-operative general investigation is required. This would normally include blood tests, ECG and chest x-ray.
===Types=== [[File:Hip fracture classification.png|thumb|Hip fracture classification.<ref> *{{cite web|url=http://www.sign.ac.uk/guidelines/fulltext/56/section7.html|title=Prevention and Management of Hip Fracture on Older People. Section 7: Surgical management|website=Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network|accessdate=2017-04-23}} Last modified 15/7/02 *Area of trochanteric fractures: {{cite web|url=https://www2.aofoundation.org/wps/portal/surgery?showPage=diagnosis&bone=Femur&segment=Proximal|title=Proximal femur|website=[[AO Foundation]]|author=Ernst Raaymakers, Inger Schipper, Rogier Simmermacher, Chris van der Werken|accessdate=2017-04-23|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170424174524/https://www2.aofoundation.org/wps/portal/surgery?showPage=diagnosis&bone=Femur&segment=Proximal|archivedate=24 April 2017|df=dmy-all}} *Area of subtrochanteric fractures: {{cite web|url=http://emedicine.medscape.com/article/1247329-overview|title=Subtrochanteric Hip Fractures|author=Mark A Lee|accessdate=2017-04-25|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170426151200/http://emedicine.medscape.com/article/1247329-overview|archivedate=26 April 2017|df=dmy-all}} Updated: Jun 22, 2016 *Area of femoral neck fractures: [https://books.google.com/books?id=z-obRfldOtMC&pg=PA519-IA2 Page 333] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171105193617/https://books.google.com/books?id=z-obRfldOtMC&pg=PA519-IA2 |date=5 November 2017 }} in: {{cite book|title=Operative Techniques in Orthopaedic Trauma Surgery|author=Paul Tornetta, III, Sam W. Wiesel|publisher=Lippincott Williams & Wilkins|year=2010|isbn=9781451102604}}</ref>]] [[File:Shf ohne dislokation medial ap.jpg|thumb|Subcapital fracture in a 92-year-old woman]] [[File:Skin folds close to a hip fracture (with arrows).jpg|thumb|Fracture (black arrow, pertrochanteric) versus a skin fold (white arrow).]] X-rays of the affected hip usually make the diagnosis obvious; [[Anteroposterior|AP]] (anteroposterior) and lateral views should be obtained.
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Capsule ! colspan="2"|Area ! colspan="2"|Classification |- | rowspan="4"|Intracapsular | colspan="2"|[[femoral head]] | [[Müller AO Classification of fractures|AO]] 31-C1 - 31-C3 | [[Pipkin classification]] |- | rowspan="3"|[[femoral neck]] | Subcapital | rowspan="3"|[[Müller AO Classification of fractures|AO]] 31-B1 - 31-B3 | rowspan="3"|[[Garden classification]], [[Pauwel's classification]] |- | Transcervical |- | Basicervical |- | rowspan="3"|Extracapsular | rowspan="2"|Trochanteric | Intertrochanteric (between the [[greater trochanter|greater]] and [[lesser trochanter]]<ref name=Dandy2009>[https://books.google.com/books?id=zxiHcX7QgsgC&pg=PA245 Page 245] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171105193617/https://books.google.com/books?id=zxiHcX7QgsgC&pg=PA245 |date=5 November 2017 }} in: {{cite book|title=Essential Orthopaedics and Trauma, 5th edition|author=David J. Dandy, Dennis J. Edwards|publisher=Elsevier Health Sciences|year=2009|isbn=9780702042096}}</ref>) | [[Müller AO Classification of fractures|AO]] 31-A1 - 31-A2 | rowspan="2"| Evans' classification (1949), Ramadier's classification (1956), Boyd and Griffin's classification (1949), Decoulx & Lavarde's classification (1969), Ender's classification (1970), Tronzo's classification (1973), [[Evans-Jensen classification]] (1975), Deburge's classification (1976), Briot's classification (1980) |- | Pertrochanteric (through the trochanters<ref name=Dandy2009/><ref name="SchipperSteyerberg2009">{{cite journal|last1=Schipper|first1=Inger B.|last2=Steyerberg|first2=Ewout W.|last3=Castelein|first3=Rene M.|last4=Vugt|first4=Arie B. van|title=Reliability of the AO/ASIF classification for pertrochanteric femoral fractures|journal=Acta Orthopaedica Scandinavica|volume=72|issue=1|year=2009|pages=36–41|doi=10.1080/000164701753606662|pmid=11327411}}</ref>) | [[Müller AO Classification of fractures|AO]] 31-A3 |- | colspan="2"|Subtrochanteric | [[Müller AO Classification of fractures|AO]] 32 | [[Seinsheimer classification]] |}
Trochanteric fractures are subdivided into either intertrochanteric (between the [[greater trochanter|greater]] and [[lesser trochanter]]<ref name=Dandy2009/>) or pertrochanteric (through the trochanters<ref name=Dandy2009/><ref name="SchipperSteyerberg2009"/>) by the [[Müller AO Classification of fractures]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www2.aofoundation.org/wps/portal/surgery?showPage=diagnosis&bone=Femur&segment=Proximal|title=Proximal femur|website=[[AO Foundation]]|author=Ernst Raaymakers, Inger Schipper, Rogier Simmermacher, Chris van der Werken|accessdate=2017-04-23|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170424174524/https://www2.aofoundation.org/wps/portal/surgery?showPage=diagnosis&bone=Femur&segment=Proximal|archivedate=24 April 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Practically, the difference between these types is minor. The terms are often used synonymously.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=n069BAAAQBAJ&pg=PA190 Page 190] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171105193617/https://books.google.com/books?id=n069BAAAQBAJ&pg=PA190 |date=5 November 2017 }} in: {{cite book|title=Global Orthopedics: Caring for Musculoskeletal Conditions and Injuries in Austere Settings|author=Richard A. Gosselin, David A. Spiegel, Michelle Foltz|publisher=Springer Science & Business|year=2014|isbn=9781461415787}}</ref><ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=DXjl7VPr9T8C&pg=PA365 Page 365] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171105193617/https://books.google.com/books?id=DXjl7VPr9T8C&pg=PA365 |date=5 November 2017 }} in: {{cite book|title=Non-Invasive Respiratory Support, Third edition: A Practical Handbook|author=Anita K. Simonds|publisher=CRC Press|year=2007|isbn=9780340809846}}</ref> An ''isolated trochanteric fracture'' involves one of the trochanters without going through the anatomical axis of the femur, and may occur in young individuals due to forceful muscle contraction.<ref name=Pope2014>[https://books.google.com/books?id=OAuqBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA303 Page 303] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171105193617/https://books.google.com/books?id=OAuqBAAAQBAJ&pg=PA303 |date=5 November 2017 }} in: {{cite book|title=Musculoskeletal Imaging E-Book|author=Thomas Pope, Hans L. Bloem, Javier Beltran, William B. Morrison, David John Wilson|edition=2|publisher=Elsevier Health Sciences|year=2014|isbn=9780323278188}}</ref> Yet, an ''isolated trochanteric fracture'' may not be regarded as a true hip fracture because it is not cross-sectional.
==Prevention== The majority of hip fractures are the result of a fall, particularly in the elderly. Therefore, identifying why the fall occurred, and implementing treatments or changes, is key to reducing the occurrence of hip fractures. Multiple contributing factors are often identified.<ref>{{Cite journal|last = Rubenstein|first = Laurence Z.|date = 2006-09-01|title = Falls in older people: epidemiology, risk factors and strategies for prevention|url = http://ageing.oxfordjournals.org/content/35/suppl_2/ii37|journal = Age and Ageing|language = en|volume = 35|issue = suppl 2|pages = ii37–ii41|doi = 10.1093/ageing/afl084|pmid = 16926202|deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20160906054315/http://ageing.oxfordjournals.org/content/35/suppl_2/ii37|archivedate = 6 September 2016|df = dmy-all}}</ref> These can include environmental factors and medical factors (such as postural hypotension or co-existing disabilities from disease such as [[Stroke]] or [[Parkinson's disease|Parkinson's Disease]] which cause visual and/or balance impairments). A recent study has identified a high incidence of undiagnosed [[Myelopathy|cervical spondylotic myelopathy]] (CSM) amongst patients with a hip fracture.<ref>{{Cite journal|last = Radcliff|first = Kristen E.|last2 = Curry|first2 = E. Patrick|last3 = Trimba|first3 = Roman|last4 = Walker|first4 = Jeffrey B.|last5 = Purtill|first5 = James J.|last6 = Austin|first6 = Matthew S.|last7 = Parviz|first7 = Javad|last8 = Vaccaro|first8 = Alexander R.|last9 = Hilibrand|first9 = Alan S.|date = 2015-11-04|title = High Incidence of Undiagnosed Cervical Myelopathy in Patients with Hip Fracture Compared to Controls|journal = Journal of Orthopaedic Trauma|doi = 10.1097/BOT.0000000000000485|pmid = 26562581|volume=30|issue = 4|pages=189–93}}</ref> This is relatively unrecognised consequent of CSM.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.myelopathy.org/the-science-of-csm.html|title = Cervical Spondylotic Myelopathy|date = |website = Myelopathy.org|publisher = |access-date = |deadurl = no|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20151118005913/http://www.myelopathy.org/the-science-of-csm.html|archivedate = 18 November 2015|df = dmy-all}}</ref>
Additionally, there is some evidence to systems designed to offer protection in the case of a fall. [[Hip protectors]], for example appear to decrease the number of hip fractures among the elderly.<ref name="San2014">{{cite journal|last1=Santesso|first1=N|last2=Carrasco-Labra|first2=A|last3=Brignardello-Petersen|first3=R|title=Hip protectors for preventing hip fractures in older people|journal=The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews|date=Mar 31, 2014|volume=3|issue=3|pages=CD001255|pmid=24687239|doi=10.1002/14651858.CD001255.pub5}}</ref> They; however, are not often used.<ref name="San2014" />
==Management== Most hip fractures are treated surgically by [[medical implant|implanting]] an [[orthosis]]. Surgical treatment outweighs the risks of nonsurgical treatment which requires extensive bedrest.<ref name=":0" /> Prolonged immobilization increases risk of thromboembolism, pneumonia, deconditioning, and decubitus ulcers. Regardless, the surgery is a major stress, particularly in the elderly. Pain is also significant, and can also result in immobilization, so patients are encouraged to become mobile as soon as possible, often with the assistance of [[physical therapy]]. [[Traction (orthopedics)|Skeletal traction]] pending surgery is not supported by the evidence.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Handoll|first=HH|author2=Queally, JM |author3=Parker, MJ |title=Pre-operative traction for hip fractures in adults|journal=Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews |date=Dec 7, 2011|issue=12|pages=CD000168|pmid=22161361|doi=10.1002/14651858.CD000168.pub3}}</ref> [[Regional nerve block]]s are useful for pain management in hip fractures.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Ritcey|first1=B|last2=Pageau|first2=P|last3=Woo|first3=MY|last4=Perry|first4=JJ|title=Regional Nerve Blocks For Hip and Femoral Neck Fractures in the Emergency Department: A Systematic Review|journal=CJEM|date=2 September 2015|pages=1–11|pmid=26330019|doi=10.1017/cem.2015.75|volume=18|issue=1}}</ref> Surgery can be performed under general anaesthesia or with neuraxial techniques - choice is based on surgical and patient factors, as outcomes such as mortality and post-procedure complications including pneumonia, MI, stroke or confusion, are not affected by anaesthetic technique.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Guay|first1=J|last2=Parker|first2=MJ|last3=Gajendragadkar|first3=PR|last4=Kopp|first4=S|title=Anaesthesia for hip fracture surgery in adults|journal=The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews|date=22 February 2016|volume=2|pages=CD000521|doi=10.1002/14651858.CD000521.pub3|pmid=26899415}}</ref>
[[Blood transfusion|Red blood cell transfusion]] is common for people undergoing hip fracture surgery due to the blood loss sustained during surgery and from the injury. Giving blood when the hemoglobin is less than 10 g/dL versus less than 8 g/dL was of unclear benefit per a 2015 Cochrane review.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Brunskill|first1=SJ|last2=Millette|first2=SL|last3=Shokoohi|first3=A|last4=Pulford|first4=EC|last5=Doree|first5=C|last6=Murphy|first6=MF|last7=Stanworth|first7=S|title=Red blood cell transfusion for people undergoing hip fracture surgery|journal=The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews|date=21 April 2015|volume=4|issue=4|pages=CD009699|pmid=25897628|doi=10.1002/14651858.CD009699.pub2}}</ref> A review in 2018 however found that waiting until the hemoglobin was less than 8 g/dL or the person had symptoms increased the risk of heart problems.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Gu |first1=WJ |last2=Gu |first2=XP |last3=Wu |first3=XD |last4=Chen |first4=H |last5=Kwong |first5=JSW |last6=Zhou |first6=LY |last7=Chen |first7=S |last8=Ma |first8=ZL |title=Restrictive Versus Liberal Strategy for Red Blood-Cell Transfusion: A Systematic Review and Meta-Analysis in Orthopaedic Patients |journal=The Journal of Bone and Joint Surgery. American Volume |date=18 April 2018 |volume=100 |issue=8 |pages=686–695 |doi=10.2106/JBJS.17.00375 |pmid=29664857}}</ref>
If operative treatment is refused or the risks of surgery are considered to be too high the main emphasis of treatment is on pain relief. Skeletal traction may be considered for long term treatment. Aggressive chest [[physiotherapy]] is needed to reduce the risk of [[pneumonia]] and skilled rehabilitation and nursing to avoid [[Bedsores|pressure sores]] and [[Deep vein thrombosis|DVT]]/[[pulmonary embolism]] Most people will be bedbound for several months. Non-operative treatment is now limited to only the most medically unstable or demented patients, or those who are nonambulatory at baseline with minimal pain during transfers.<ref name=":0" />
Surgery on the same day or day following the break is estimated to reduce postoperative mortality in people who are medically stable.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Sobolev|first=Boris|last2=Guy|first2=Pierre|last3=Sheehan|first3=Katie Jane|last4=Kuramoto|first4=Lisa|last5=Sutherland|first5=Jason M.|last6=Levy|first6=Adrian R.|last7=Blair|first7=James A.|last8=Bohm|first8=Eric|last9=Kim|first9=Jason D.|date=2018-08-07|title=Mortality effects of timing alternatives for hip fracture surgery|url=http://www.cmaj.ca/content/190/31/E923|journal=CMAJ|language=en|volume=190|issue=31|pages=E923–E932|doi=10.1503/cmaj.171512|issn=0820-3946|pmid=30087128|pmc=6078777}}</ref>
===Intracapsular fractures=== [[File:Shf medial verschraubt crop.jpg|thumb|Fracture treated with [[cannulated screw]]s]]
For low-grade fractures (Garden types 1 and 2), standard treatment is fixation of the fracture in situ with screws or a sliding screw/plate device. This treatment can also be offered for displaced fractures after the fracture has been reduced.
Fractures managed by [[closed reduction]] can possibly be treated by percutaneously inserted screws.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www2.aofoundation.org/wps/portal/!ut/p/a0/04_Sj9CPykssy0xPLMnMz0vMAfGjzOKN_A0M3D2DDbz9_UMMDRyDXQ3dw9wMDAzMjfULsh0VAbWjLW0!/?bone=Femur&segment=Proximal&showPage=D&contentUrl=srg/popup/further_reading/PFxM2/31/661_32-Neck_fxs_surg_treat.jsp|title=Fractures of the femoral neck (31-B)|website=OA Foundation|author=Reinhard Hoffmann, Norbert P Haas|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170427193030/https://www2.aofoundation.org/wps/portal/!ut/p/a0/04_Sj9CPykssy0xPLMnMz0vMAfGjzOKN_A0M3D2DDbz9_UMMDRyDXQ3dw9wMDAzMjfULsh0VAbWjLW0!/?bone=Femur&segment=Proximal&showPage=D&contentUrl=srg%2Fpopup%2Ffurther_reading%2FPFxM2%2F31%2F661_32-Neck_fxs_surg_treat.jsp|archivedate=27 April 2017|df=dmy-all}}, citing: {{cite book|title=OA Principles of Fracture management|author=T. P. Rüedi, R. E. Buckley, C.G. Moran|publisher=Thieme Medical Publishers|year=2007|isbn=9781588905567}}</ref>
In elderly patients with displaced or intracapsular fractures many surgeons prefer to undertake a [[hemiarthroplasty]], replacing the broken part of the bone with a metal implant. The advantage is that the patient can mobilize without having to wait for healing.
In elderly patients who are medically well and still active, a [[total hip replacement]] may be indicated.
Traction is contraindicated in femoral neck fractures due to it affecting blood flow to the head of the femur.<ref>{{cite book |author=Tintinalli, Judith E. |title=Emergency Medicine: A Comprehensive Study Guide (Emergency Medicine (Tintinalli)) |publisher=McGraw-Hill Companies |location=New York |year=2010 |pages= |isbn=978-0-07-148480-0 |oclc= |doi= }}</ref>
===Trochanteric fracture=== [[File:Cdm hip implant 348.jpg|thumb|Fracture supported by [[dynamic hip screw]]]]
A trochanteric fracture, below the neck of the femur, has a good chance of healing.
[[Reduction (orthopedic surgery)|Closed reduction]] may not be satisfactory and [[Reduction (orthopedic surgery)|open reduction]] then becomes necessary.<ref name=oa2017>Subtypes of trochanteric fractures: {{cite web|url=https://www2.aofoundation.org/wps/portal/surgery?showPage=diagnosis&bone=Femur&segment=Proximal|title=Proximal femur|website=OA Foundation|author=Ernst Raaymakers, Inger Schipper, Rogier Simmermacher, Chris van der Werken|accessdate=2017-04-23|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170424174524/https://www2.aofoundation.org/wps/portal/surgery?showPage=diagnosis&bone=Femur&segment=Proximal|archivedate=24 April 2017|df=dmy-all}}</ref> The use of open reduction has been reported as 8-13% among pertrochanteric fractures, and 52% among intertrochanteric fractures.<ref name="BoldinSeibert2009">{{cite journal|last1=Boldin|first1=Christian|last2=Seibert|first2=Franz J|last3=Fankhauser|first3=Florian|last4=Peicha|first4=Gerolf|last5=Grechenig|first5=Wolfgang|last6=Szyszkowitz|first6=Rudolf|title=The proximal femoral nail (PFN) - a minimal invasive treatment of unstable proximal femoral fractures: A prospective study of 55 patients with a follow-up of 15 months|journal=Acta Orthopaedica Scandinavica|volume=74|issue=1|year=2009|pages=53–58|doi=10.1080/00016470310013662|pmid=12635794}} *This study cites the following primary source: <br>{{cite journal|author=Friedl W, Colombo-Benkmann M, Dockter S, et al.|title=Gammanagel-osteosynthes per- und subtrochanterer Femurfrakturen|journal=Chirurg|year=1994|volume=65}}</ref> Both intertrochanteric and pertrochanteric fractures may be treated by a [[dynamic hip screw]] and plate, or an [[intramedullary rod]].<ref name=oa2017/>
The fracture typically takes 3–6 months to heal. As it is only common in elderly, removal of the [[dynamic hip screw]] is usually not recommended to avoid unnecessary risk of second operation and the increased risk of re-fracture after implant removal. The most common cause for hip fractures in the elderly is osteoporosis; if this is the case, treatment of the osteoporosis can well reduce the risk of further fracture. Only young patients tend to consider having it removed; the implant may function as a [[stress riser]], increasing the risk of a break if another accident occurs.
===Subtrochanteric fractures=== Subtrochanteric fractures may be treated with an [[intramedullary nail]] or a screw-plate construction and may require [[Traction (orthopedics)|traction]] pre-operatively, though this practice is uncommon. It is unclear if any specific type of nail results in different outcomes than any other type of nail.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Queally|first1=JM|last2=Harris|first2=E|last3=Handoll|first3=HH|last4=Parker|first4=MJ|title=Intramedullary nails for extracapsular hip fractures in adults|journal=The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews|date=Sep 12, 2014|volume=9|issue=9|pages=CD004961|pmid=25212485|doi=10.1002/14651858.CD004961.pub4}}</ref>
===Rehabilitation=== Rehabilitation has been proven to increase [[activities of daily living|daily functional status]]. It is unclear if the use of [[anabolic steroid]]s effects recovery.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Farooqi|first1=V|last2=van den Berg|first2=ME|last3=Cameron|first3=ID|last4=Crotty|first4=M|title=Anabolic steroids for rehabilitation after hip fracture in older people|journal=The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews|date=Oct 6, 2014|volume=10|issue=10|pages=CD008887|pmid=25284341|doi=10.1002/14651858.CD008887.pub2}}</ref>
There is not enough evidence to ascertain what are the best strategies to promote walking after hip fracture surgery.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Handoll|first=Helen Hg|last2=Sherrington|first2=Catherine|last3=Mak|first3=Jenson Cs|date=2011-03-16|title=Interventions for improving mobility after hip fracture surgery in adults|journal=The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews|issue=3|pages=CD001704|doi=10.1002/14651858.CD001704.pub4|issn=1469-493X|pmid=21412873|url=http://www.scielo.br/scielo.php?script=sci_arttext&pid=S1516-31802011000600012|format=Submitted manuscript}}</ref>
=== Nutrition supplementation === Oral supplements with non-protein energy, protein, vitamins and minerals started before or early after surgery may prevent complications during the first year after hip fracture in aged adults; without seemingly effects on mortality.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Avenell|first=A|last2=Smith|first2=TO|last3=Curtain|first3=J|last4=Mak|first4=JCS|last5=Myint|first5=PK|title=Nutritional supplementation for hip fracture aftercare in older people|journal=The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews|publication-date=30 November 2016|volume=11|pages=CD001880|doi=10.1002/14651858.CD001880.pub6|pmid=27898998|year=2016|hdl=2164/9672}}</ref>
==Complications== [[Nonunion]], failure of the fracture to heal, is common in fractures of the neck of the femur, but much more rare with other types of hip fracture. [[Avascular necrosis]] of the femoral head occurs frequently (20%) in intracapsular hip fractures, because the blood supply is interrupted.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/706805938|title=Essentials of musculoskeletal care|date=2010|publisher=American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons|others=Sarwark, John F.|isbn=9780892035793|location=Rosemont, Ill.|oclc=706805938}}</ref>
[[Malunion]], healing of the fracture in a distorted position, is very common. The thigh muscles tend to pull on the bone fragments, causing them to overlap and reunite incorrectly. [[bone shortening|Shortening]], [[varus deformity]], [[valgus deformity]], and [[rotational malunion]] all occur often because the fracture may be unstable and collapse before it heals. This may not be as much of a concern in patients with limited independence and mobility.
Hip fractures rarely result in [[neurological]] or [[Blood vessel|vascular]] injury.
===Surgical=== Deep or superficial wound infection has an approximate incidence of 2%. It is a serious problem as superficial infection may lead to deep infection. This may cause infection of the healing bone and contamination of the implants. It is difficult to eliminate infection in the presence of metal foreign bodies such as implants. Bacteria inside the implants are inaccessible to the body's defence system and to antibiotics. The management is to attempt to suppress the infection with drainage and antibiotics until the bone is healed. Then the implant should be removed, following which the infection may clear up.
Implant failure may occur; the metal screws and plate can break, back out, or cut out superiorly and enter the joint. This occurs either through inaccurate implant placement or if the fixation does not hold in weak and brittle bone. In the event of failure, the surgery may be redone, or changed to a [[total hip replacement]].
Mal-positioning: The fracture can be fixed and subsequently heal in an incorrect position; especially rotation. This may not be a severe problem or may require subsequent [[osteotomy]] surgery for correction.
===Medical=== Many people are unwell before breaking a hip; it is common for the break to have been caused by a [[Falling (accident)|fall]] due to some illness, especially in the elderly. Nevertheless, the stress of the injury, and a likely surgery, increases the risk of medical illness including [[myocardial infarction|heart attack]], [[cerebrovascular accident|stroke]], and [[pneumonia|chest infection]].
Hip fracture patients are at considerable risk for [[Venous thrombosis|thromboemoblism]], blood clots that dislodge and travel in the bloodstream.<ref name=":0" /> [[Deep venous thrombosis]] (DVT) is when the blood in the leg veins clots and causes pain and swelling. This is very common after hip fracture as the circulation is stagnant and the blood is hypercoagulable as a response to injury. DVT can occur without causing symptoms. A [[pulmonary embolism]] (PE) occurs when clotted blood from a DVT comes loose from the leg veins and passes up to the lungs. Circulation to parts of the lungs are cut off which can be very dangerous. Fatal PE may have an incidence of 2% after hip fracture and may contribute to illness and mortality in other cases.
[[Mental confusion]] is extremely common following a hip fracture. It usually clears completely, but the disorienting experience of pain, immobility, loss of independence, moving to a strange place, surgery, and drugs combine to cause [[delirium]] or accentuate pre-existing [[dementia]].
[[Urinary tract infection]] (UTI) can occur. Patients are immobilized and in bed for many days; they are frequently [[urinary catheterization|catheterised]], commonly causing infection.
Prolonged immobilization and difficulty moving make it hard to avoid [[bedsores|pressure sores]] on the sacrum and heels of patients with hip fractures. Whenever possible, early mobilization is advocated; otherwise, [[alternating pressure mattress]]es should be used.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wheelessonline.com/ortho/fractures_of_the_femoral_neck|title=Fractures of the Femoral Neck|website=Wheeless' Textbook of Orthopaedics|publisher=[[Duke University School of Medicine]]|accessdate=27 January 2008|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080118043826/http://www.wheelessonline.com/ortho/fractures_of_the_femoral_neck|archivedate=18 January 2008|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wheelessonline.com/ortho/intertrochanteric_fractures|title=Intertrochanteric Fractures|website=Wheeless' Textbook of Orthopaedics|publisher=[[Duke University School of Medicine]]|accessdate=27 January 2008|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080118054018/http://www.wheelessonline.com/ortho/intertrochanteric_fractures|archivedate=18 January 2008|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/63321.php |title=Damage Control Orthopaedics: Patient Stabilization, Early Mobilization |website=74th Annual Meeting of the [[American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons]] briefing |date=18 Feb 2007 |publisher=[[Medical News Today]] |accessdate=27 January 2008 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081122045136/http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/63321.php |archivedate=22 November 2008 |df=dmy-all }} </ref>
==Prognosis== Hip fractures are very dangerous episodes especially for elderly and frail patients. The risk of dying from the stress of the surgery and the injury in the first thirty days is about 10%. At one year after fracture this may reach 30%.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Sedlář M, Kvasnička J, Krška Z, Tománková T, Linhart A |title=Early and subacute inflammatory response and long-term survival after hip trauma and surgery |journal=[[Archives Gerontol. Geriatr.]] |date=12 February 2015 |volume=60 |issue=3 |pages=431–6 |pmid=25704919 |doi=10.1016/j.archger.2015.02.002 }}{{closed access}}</ref> If the condition is untreated the pain and immobility imposed on the patient increase that risk. Problems such as [[Bedsores|pressure sores]] and [[Pneumonia|chest infections]] are all increased by immobility. The prognosis of untreated hip fractures is very poor.
===Post operation=== Among those affected over the age of 65, 40% are transferred directly to long-term care facilities, long-term rehabilitation facilities, or [[nursing home]]s; most of those affected require some sort of living assistance from family or home-care providers. 50% permanently require [[walker (tool)|walker]]s, canes, or crutches for mobility; all require some sort of mobility assistance throughout the healing process. Most of the recovery of walking ability and activities of daily living occurs within 6 months of the fracture.<ref name=Dyer2016>{{cite journal |last1=Dyer |first1=Suzanne M. |last2=Crotty |first2=Maria |last3=Fairhall |first3=Nicola |last4=Magaziner |first4=Jay |last5=Beaupre |first5=Lauren A. |last6=Cameron |first6=Ian D. |last7=Sherrington |first7=Catherine |title=A critical review of the long-term disability outcomes following hip fracture |journal=BMC Geriatrics |date=2 September 2016 |volume=16 |issue=1 |pages=158 |doi=10.1186/s12877-016-0332-0|pmid=27590604 |pmc=5010762 }}</ref> After the fracture about half of older people recover their pre-fracture level of mobility and ability to perform instrumental activities of daily living, while 40–70 % regain their level of independence for basic activities of daily living.<ref name=Dyer2016/>
Among those affected over the age of 50, approximately 25% die within the next year due to complications such as [[thrombus|blood clots]] ([[deep venous thrombosis]], [[pulmonary embolism]]), [[infection]]s, and [[pneumonia]].{{Citation needed|date=April 2009}}
Patients with hip fractures are at high risk for future fractures including hip, wrist, shoulder, and spine. After treatment of the acute fracture, the risk of future fractures should be addressed. Currently, only 1 in 4 patients after a hip fracture receives treatment and work up for osteoporosis, the underlying cause of most of the fractures. Current treatment standards include the starting of a [[bisphosphonate]] to reduce future fracture risk by up to 50%.{{Citation needed|date=July 2018}}
==Epidemiology== [[File:Hip_fracture_incidence_world_map.svg|thumb|upright=1.3|Age-standardised hip fracture rates.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kanis|first=J. A.|last2=Odén|first2=A.|last3=McCloskey|first3=E. V.|last4=Johansson|first4=H.|last5=Wahl|first5=D. A.|last6=Cooper|first6=C.|date=September 2012|title=A systematic review of hip fracture incidence and probability of fracture worldwide|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3421108/|journal=Osteoporosis International|volume=23|issue=9|pages=2239–2256|doi=10.1007/s00198-012-1964-3|issn=0937-941X|pmc=3421108|pmid=22419370}}</ref>{{legend|green|Low (< 150 / 100 000)}}{{legend|orange|Medium (150-250 / 100 000)}}{{legend|red|High (> 250 / 100 000)}}]] Hip fractures are seen globally and are a serious concern at the individual and population level. By 2050 it is estimated that there will be 6 million cases of hip fractures worldwide.<ref name=Kannus1996>{{cite journal |vauthors=Kannus P, Parkkari J, Sievanen H, Heinonen A, Vouri I, Jarvinen M | year = 1996 | title = Epidemiology of hip fractures | doi = 10.1016/8756-3282(95)00381-9 | journal = Bone | volume = 18 | issue = | pages = 57–63 }}</ref> One study published in 2001 found that in the US alone, 310,000 individuals were hospitalized due to hip fractures, which can account for 30% of Americans who were hospitalized that year.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Huddleston JM, Whitford KJ | year = 2001 | title = Medical Care of Elderly Patients with Hip Fractures | url = | journal = Mayo Clinic Proceedings | volume = 76 | issue = 3| pages = 295–300 | doi=10.4065/76.3.295| pmid = 11243276 }}</ref> Another study found that in 2011, femur neck fractures were among the most expensive conditions seen in US hospitals, with an aggregated cost of nearly $4.9 billion for 316,000 inpatient hospitalizations.<ref>Torio CM, Andrews RM. National Inpatient Hospital Costs: The Most Expensive Conditions by Payer, 2011. HCUP Statistical Brief #160. Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality, Rockville, MD. August 2013. {{cite web |url=http://hcup-us.ahrq.gov/reports/statbriefs/sb160.jsp |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2017-05-01 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170314171958/https://www.hcup-us.ahrq.gov/reports/statbriefs/sb160.jsp |archivedate=14 March 2017 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> Rates of hip fractures is declining in the United States, possibly due to increased use of bisphosphonates and risk management.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Brauer|first=Carmen A.|last2=Coca-Perraillon|first2=Marcelo|last3=Cutler|first3=David M.|last4=Rosen|first4=Allison B.|date=2009-10-14|title=Incidence and mortality of hip fractures in the United States|journal=JAMA|volume=302|issue=14|pages=1573–1579|doi=10.1001/jama.2009.1462|issn=1538-3598|pmc=4410861|pmid=19826027}}</ref> [[Falling (accident)|Falling]], poor vision, weight and height are all seen as [[risk factors]]. Falling is one of the most common risk factors for hip fractures. Approximately 90% of hip fractures are attributed to falls from standing height.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Cumming RG, Nevitt MC, Cummings SR | year = 1997 | title = Epidemiology of Hip Fractures | url = | journal = Epidemiology Review | volume = 19 | issue = 2| pages = 244–257 | doi=10.1093/oxfordjournals.epirev.a017956}}</ref>
Given the high morbidity and mortality associated with hip fractures and the cost to the health system, in England and Wales, the [[National Hip Fracture Database]] is a mandatory nationwide audit of care and treatment of all hip fractures.
===Population===
All populations experience hip fractures but numbers vary with race, gender, and age. Women suffer three times as many hip fractures as men.<ref>{{cite web|title=Hip Fractures Among Older Adults|url=https://www.cdc.gov/HomeandRecreationalSafety/Falls/adulthipfx.html|website=CDC|publisher=CDC|accessdate=13 May 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150508103238/http://www.cdc.gov/HomeandRecreationalSafety/Falls/adulthipfx.html|archivedate=8 May 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref> In a lifetime, men have an estimated 6% risk whereas postmenopausal women have an estimated 14% risk of suffering a hip fracture.<ref name=Lauritzen1997>{{cite journal | author = Lauritzen JB | year = 1997 | title = Hip fractures: Epidemiology, risk factors, falls, energy absorption, hip protectors, and prevention | url = | journal = Dan Med Bull | volume = 44 | issue = 2| pages = 155–168 }}</ref> These statistics provide insight over a lifespan and conclude that women are twice as likely to suffer a hip fracture. The overwhelming majority of hip fractures occur in white individuals while blacks and Hispanics have a lower rate of them. This may be due to their generally greater bone density and also because whites have longer overall lifespan and higher likelihood of reaching an advanced age where the risk of breaking a hip goes up.<ref name=Lauritzen1997/> Deprivation is also a key factor: in England it has been found that people in the poorest parts of the country are more likely to fracture a hip and less likely to recover well than those in the least deprived areas.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Bardsley|first1=Martin|title=Focus on: Hip fracture|url=http://www.qualitywatch.org.uk/focus-on/hip-fracture|website=QualityWatch|publisher=Nuffield Trust & Health Foundation|accessdate=13 May 2015|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150515044225/http://www.qualitywatch.org.uk/focus-on/hip-fracture|archivedate=15 May 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===Age related===
Age is the most dominant factor in hip fracture injuries, with most cases occurring in people over 75. The increase of age is related to the increase of the incidence of hip fracture,<ref name=Kannus1996/> which is the most frequent cause of hospitalization in centenarians, overcoming congestive heart failure and respiratory infection.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Rodríguez-Molinero|first1=Alejandro|last2=Yuste|first2=Antonio|last3=Banegas|first3=José Ramón|title=High incidence of hip fracture in Spanish centenarians|journal=J Am Geriatr Soc|date=2010|volume=58|issue=2|pages=403–5|doi=10.1111/j.1532-5415.2009.02706.x|pmid=20370877}}</ref> Falls are the most common cause of hip fractures, around 30-60% of older adults fall each year. This increases the risk for hip fracture and leads to the increase risk of death in older individuals, the rate of one year [[mortality rate|mortality]] is seen from 12-37%.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Rubenstein LZ, Josephson KR | year = 2002 | title = The Epidemiology of Falls and Syncope | url = | journal = Clinic in Geriatrics Medicine | volume = 18 | issue = | pages = 141–150 }}</ref> For those remaining patients who do not suffer from mortality, half of them need assistance and cannot live independently. Also, older adults sustain hip fractures because of [[osteoporosis]], which is a degenerative disease due to age and decrease in bone mass. The average age for suffering a hip fracture is 77 years old for women and 72 years old for men.<ref>Baumgaertner MR, Higgins TF. (2002) Femoral Neck Fractures. Rockwood & Green’s Fractures in Adults. 1579-1586</ref> This shows how closely age is related to hip fractures.
==References== {{Reflist}}
== External links == {{Medical resources | ICD10 = {{ICD10|S|72|0|s|70}} | eMedicine1 = 825363 | meSH1 = 68006620 | OrthoInfo = A00392 }} {{Commons category|Hip fractures}} *[http://www.wheelessonline.com/ortho/fractures_of_the_femoral_neck Fractures of the Femoral Neck] Wheeless Textbook of Orthopaedics *[http://www.wheelessonline.com/ortho/intertrochanteric_fractures Intertrochanteric Fractures] Wheeless' Textbook of Orthopaedics
{{Fractures}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2011}}

revision.comment: en-GB
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2017}} {{Use British English|date=September 2017}} [[File:Memorial to John James Hall in Exeter Cathedral.jpg|thumb|Memorial to John James Hall in the floor of the Syke Chantry in the north transept of [[Exeter Cathedral]] underneath the astronomical clock which he restored.]] '''John James Hall''' FRAS (11 December 1845 – 15 January 1941) was an eminent [[Horology|horologist]] and author who restored many early clocks.<ref>Monthly Notices of the [[Royal Astronomical Society]]. Vol 102. p.65</ref>
==Life==
John James Hall spent his working life as an employee of the [[London and South Western Railway]] from 1865, but on retirement devoted his time to horology. He made over 200 contributions to ''The Horological Journal'', ''[[The English Mechanic and World of Science]]'', ''Watch and Clockmaker'' and other journals.
His best known accomplishments were the restoration of the fourteenth-century astronomical clocks in [[St Mary's Church, Ottery St Mary]] in 1907<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=London Ottregians. Visit to Devonshire |url=http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000511/19070521/026/0006 |newspaper=Exeter and Plymouth Gazette |location=Exeter |date=21 May 1907 |access-date=15 September 2015|via = [[British Newspaper Archive]]|subscription=yes}}</ref> and [[Exeter Cathedral]] in 1910.<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=England’s Oldest Clock |url=http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000576/19100827/008/0003 |newspaper=Aberdeen Journal |location=Aberdeen |date=27 August 1910 |access-date=15 September 2015|via = [[British Newspaper Archive]]|subscription=yes}}</ref>
He designed a new clock for Exeter Public Library which was set going in 1931. One of his major areas of study was the life and work of Jacob Lovelace of Exeter. He also published his complete articles in ''Fasces Exonienses''.
He was elected a Fellow of the [[Royal Astronomical Society]] on 10 February 1899. He was also a Fellow of the [[British Horological Institute]], the [[Royal Meteorological Society|Meteorological Society]], the [[National Geographic Society]] of Washington, and the [[:fr:Société royale belge d'astronomie|Societe d’Astronomie et du Physique du Globe, Bruxelles]].<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=Noted Horologist. Death of Mr. J.J. Hall at Honiton |url=http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000329/19410117/059/0005 |newspaper=Western Morning News |location=Exeter |date=17 January 1941 |access-date=15 September 2015|via = [[British Newspaper Archive]]|subscription=yes}}</ref>
His ashes were interred in the Syke Chantry in the north transept of [[Exeter Cathedral]], below the clock he had restored.<ref>{{cite news |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=Cathedral Ceremony. Ashes of Honiton Horologist Interred at Exeter |url=http://www.britishnewspaperarchive.co.uk/viewer/bl/0000329/19410117/059/0005 |newspaper=Western Morning News |location=Exeter |date=22 January 1941 |access-date=15 September 2015|via = [[British Newspaper Archive]]|subscription=yes}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}

web|url=http://www.medcyclopaedia.com/library/topics/volume_iii_1/b/bosworth_fracture_dislocation.aspx|title=Bosworth fracture dislocation|publisher=[[General Electric|GE]]|work=Medcyclopaedia}} |- | when struck from side by car bumper || [http://medical-dictionary.thefreedictionary.com/bumper+fracture ''Bumper fracture''] at [[TheFreeDictionary.com]] |- | C || [[Chance fracture]] || [[George [[François Chopart]] || foot dislocation through talonavicular and calcaneocuboid joints with associated fractures, usually after ankle twisting.treated in a non weight bearing cast for 6–8 weeks|| || | D || [[Duverney fracture]] || [[Guichard Joseph Duverney|Joseph Guichard Duverney]] || isolated fracture of the iliac wing || direct trauma || {{cite Elsevier Health Sciences, 2008. {{ISBN|978-0-443-06876-8}}. |- | J || [[Jefferson fracture]] || [[Geoffrey Jefferson|Sir Geoffrey Jefferson]] || fracture of [[Atlas (anatomy)|first cervical vertebra]] || compression of neck || {{WhoNamedIt|synd|1091|Jefferson fracture}} |- | J || [[Jones fracture]] || [[Robert Jones (surgeon)|Sir Robert Jones]] || fracture of base of 5th metatarsal extending into intermetatarsal joint || inversion of ankle || [http://www.wheelessonline.com/ortho/jones_fracture ''Jones fracture''] at Wheeless' Textbook of Orthopaedics online |- | L || [[LeFort fracture|Le Fort fractures]] || [[René Le Fort]] || series of facial fractures || direct trauma to face || {{WhoNamedIt|synd|3144|LeFort I}}

{{WhoNamedIt|synd|3146|LeFort III}} |- | L || [[Le Fort's fracture of the ankle]] || [[Léon Clément Le Fort]] || vertical fracture of distal [[fibula]] with avulsion of [[medial malleolus]] || ||{{WhoNamedIt|synd|3149|LeFort's fracture of the ankle}} |- | L || [[Lisfranc fracture]] || [[Jacques Lisfranc de St. Martin]] || fracture dislocation of midfoot || forced plantar flexion of foot or dropping heavy weight on foot || {{WhoNamedIt|synd|3053|Lisfranc fracture}} |- | M || [[Maisonneuve fracture]] || [[Jules Germain François Maisonneuve]] || spiral fracture of proximal [[fibula]] || external rotation of ankle || [http://www.wheelessonline.com/ortho/maisonneuve_fracture ''Maisonneuve fracture''] at Wheeless' Textbook of Orthopaedics online |- | M || [[Malgaigne's fracture]] || [[Joseph-François Malgaigne]] || vertical [[pelvic fracture]] through both pubic rami and the [[Ilium (bone)|ilium]] or [[sacroiliac joint]] with vertical displacement || high energy impact to pelvis (front to back) || [http://medical-dictionary.thefreedictionary.com/Malgaigne%27s+fracture+of+pelvis ''Malgaigne's fracture''] at [[TheFreeDictionary.com]] |- | M || [[March fracture]] || [[Marching]] || stress fracture of a metatarsal shaft || heavy or unaccustomed exercise || [http://emedicine.medscape.com/article/85746-overview ''Metatarsal Stress Fracture''] at [[eMedicine]] |- | M || [[Monteggia fracture]] || [[Giovanni Battista Monteggia]] || proximal [[ulna]] fracture with dislocation of [[radial head]] || blow to forearm ||{{WhoNamedIt|synd|2151|Monteggia fracture}} |- | M || [[Moore's fracture]] || [[Edward Mott Moore]] || [[distal radius]] fracture with [[ulna]]r dislocation and entrapment of styloid process under annular ligament || || [http://medical-dictionary.thefreedictionary.com/Moore%27s+fracture ''Moore's fracture''] at [[TheFreeDictionary.com]] |- | P || [[Pipkin fracture-dislocation]] || G. Pipkin || posterior dislocation of hip with avulsion fracture of fragment of femoral head by the [[Round ligament of the femur|ligamentum teres]] || impact to the knee with the hip flexed (dashboard injury) || [http://www.wheelessonline.com/ortho/type_ii_v_posterior_fracture_dislocations Type II-V: ''Posterior Fracture Dislocations''] at Wheeless' Textbook of Orthopaedics online |- | P || [[Pott's fracture]]also known as '''Dupuytren's fracture''' || [[Percival Pott]] || [[Ankle#Fractures|bimalleolar fracture]] of the ankle || eversion of ankle || {{WhoNamedIt|synd|1126|Pott's fracture}} |- | R || [[Rolando fracture]] || [[Silvio Rolando]] || intra articular comminuted fracture of base of first metacarpal || axial load along the metacarpal causing splitting of the proximal articular surface || [http://www.wheelessonline.com/ortho/rolandos_fracture ''Rolando's fracture''] at Wheeless' Textbook of Orthopaedics online |- | R || [[Runner's fracture]] || [[Running]] || [[stress fracture]] of distal [[fibula]] 3–8 cm above the [[lateral malleolus]] || repeated axial stress on fibula || [https://books.google.com/books?id=KHSRuHUjQq4C&pg=PA331&lpg=PA331&dq=runner%27s+fracture&source=bl&ots=W6Cq7563FB&sig=Oqb60ykyGOW7WUnehSU5wK7y2F0&hl=en&ei=hsHLSa_VLsOrjAeGk7DRCQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&resnum=5&ct=result#PPA331,M1 Google books result] Marko Pećina, Ivan Bojanić. ''Overuse injuries of the Musculoskeletal System'', page 331. Informa Health Care, 2004. {{ISBN|978-0-8493-1428-5}}. |- | S || [[Salter–Harris fracture]] || R.B. Salter, W.R. HarrisInjuries involving the epiphyseal plate. RB Salter, WR Harris. ''JBJS'' (1963) 45: 587–632. || fractures involving a [[Epiphyseal plate|growth plate]] || various || [http://emedicine.medscape.com/article/412956-overview ''Salter–Harris fractures''] at [[Medscape]] |- | S || [[Segond fracture]] || [[Paul Segond]] || lateral tibial plateau avulsion fracture with anterior cruciate ligament tear || internal rotation of the knee || {{WhoNamedIt|synd|3483|Segond fracture}} |- | S || [[Shepherd's fracture]] || [[Francis J. Shepherd]] || fracture of the lateral tubercle of the posterior process of the talus || || [http://www.mondofacto.com/facts/dictionary?Shepherd%27s+fracture ''Shepherd's fracture''] at Mondofacto online medical dictionary |- | S || [[Smith's fracture]] || [[Robert William Smith (surgeon)|Robert William Smith]] || [[distal radius]] fracture with volar displacement || fall on outstretched hand with wrist in flexed position || {{WhoNamedIt|synd|2150|Smith's fracture}} |- | S || [[Stieda fracture]] || [[Alfred Stieda]] || avulsion fracture of the medial femoral condyle at the origin of the medial collateral ligament || || [http://medical-dictionary.thefreedictionary.com/Stieda%27s+fracture ''Stieda's fracture''] at [[TheFreeDictionary.com]] |- | T || [[Tillaux fracture]] || [[Paul Jules Tillaux]] || [[Salter–Harris fracture|Salter–Harris III]] fracture of the [[tibia]] || forced lateral rotation of foot || {{WhoNamedIt|synd|3849|Tillaux fracture}} |- | T || [[Toddler's fracture]] || [[Toddler]]s || undisplaced spiral fracture of distal [[tibia]] in children under 8 years old || low-energy trauma, often rotational || [http://www.wheelessonline.com/ortho/the_toddlers_fracture_revisited ''The toddler's fracture revisited''] at Wheeless' Textbook of Orthopaedics online |} == Notes == {{reflist}} [[Category:Lists of medical eponyms|Fractures]]

This is a list of [[fentanyl]] [[Structural analog|analogues]], including both compounds developed by pharmaceutical companies for legitimate medical use, and those which have been sold as [[designer drug]]s and reported to national drug control agencies such as the [[Drug Enforcement Administration|DEA]], or transnational agencies such as the [[EMCDDA]] and [[UNODC]].<ref name=pmid25976511>{{cite journal | vauthors = Mounteney J, Giraudon I, Denissov G, Griffiths P | title = Fentanyls: Are we missing the signs? Highly potent and on the rise in Europe | journal = The International Journal on Drug Policy | volume = 26 | issue = 7 | pages = 626–31 | date = July 2015 | pmid = 25976511 | doi = 10.1016/j.drugpo.2015.04.003 }}</ref><ref name=pmid28713291>{{cite journal | vauthors = Zawilska JB | title = An Expanding World of Novel Psychoactive Substances: Opioids | journal = Frontiers in Psychiatry | volume = 8 | pages = 110 | year = 2017 | pmid = 28713291 | pmc = 5492455 | doi = 10.3389/fpsyt.2017.00110 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.unodc.org/documents/scientific/Recommended_methods_for_the_identification_and_analysis_of_Fentanyl.pdf | title = Recommended Methods for the Identification and Analysis of Fentanyl and its Analogues in Biological Specimens. | work = United Nations Office on Drugs and Crime | date = November 2017}}</ref><ref name=pmid24635521>{{cite journal | vauthors = Vardanyan RS, Hruby VJ | title = Fentanyl-related compounds and derivatives: current status and future prospects for pharmaceutical applications | journal = Future Medicinal Chemistry | volume = 6 | issue = 4 | pages = 385–412 | date = March 2014 | pmid = 24635521 | pmc = 4137794 | doi = 10.4155/fmc.13.215 }}</ref><ref name=pmid29042317>{{cite journal | vauthors = Armenian P, Vo KT, Barr-Walker J, Lynch KL | title = Fentanyl, fentanyl analogs and novel synthetic opioids: A comprehensive review | journal = Neuropharmacology | volume = 134 | issue = Pt A | pages = 121–132 | date = October 2017 | pmid = 29042317 | doi = 10.1016/j.neuropharm.2017.10.016 | url = http://www.escholarship.org/uc/item/8xh0s7nf | format = Submitted manuscript }}</ref> This is not a comprehensive listing of fentanyl analogues, as more than 1400 compounds from this family have been described in the scientific and patent literature,<ref>[http://www.forensicscience.pl/pfs/59_skulska.pdf Skulska A, Kała M, Parczewski A. Fentanyl and its analogs in the forensic laboratory. Medical and analytical problems. ''Probl Forensic Sci''. 2004;59:127-42.]</ref><ref>{{cite journal|first1=Nektaria|last1=Misailidi|first2=Ioannis|last2=Papoutsis|first3=Panagiota|last3=Nikolaou|first4=Artemisia|last4=Dona|title=Fentanyls continue to replace heroin in the drug arena: the cases of ocfentanil and carfentanil|journal=Forensic Toxicology|date=January 2018|issn=1860-8965|pages=12–32|volume=36|issue=1|doi=10.1007/s11419-017-0379-4|pmid=29367860|pmc=5754389|first5=Chara|last5=Spiliopoulou|first6=Sotiris|last6=Athanaselis}}</ref> but it includes all notable compounds that have reached late-stage human clinical trials, or which have been identified as having been sold as designer drugs.
In the United States, the [[Drug Enforcement Agency]] placed the broadly defined class of "Fentanyl-Related Substances" on the [[List of Schedule I drugs (US)|list of Schedule I drugs]] in 2018, making it illegal to manufacture, distribute, or possess fentanyl analogs.<ref>{{Cite journal| pmid = 29932611| year = 2018| last1 = Drug Enforecement Administration| first1 = Department of Justice| title = Schedules of Controlled Substances:Temporary Placement of Fentanyl-Related Substances in Schedule I. Temporary amendment; temporary scheduling order| journal = Federal Register| volume = 83| issue = 25| pages = 5188–92}}</ref>

==Analogue controls== Several jurisdictions have implemented [[Federal Analogue Act|analogue law]] controls of fentanyl analogues in an attempt to pre-emptively ban novel derivatives before they appear on the market. One representative example is the New Zealand provisions enacted in 1988 in response to the first wave of fentanyl derivatives. This bans a set of structures as follows;
"Fentanyl analogues, in which the N-[1-(2-phenethyl)-4-piperidyl]aniline nucleus has additional radicals, either alone or in combination, attached as follows:
(a) an acetyl, propionyl, butenoyl or butanoyl radical, attached to the aniline nitrogen atom:
(b) 1 or more alkyl radicals, with up to 10 carbon atoms in total, attached to the ethyl moeity:
(c) any combination of up to 5 alkyl radicals and/or alkoxy radicals (each with up to 6 carbon atoms, including cyclic radicals) and/or halogen radicals, attached to each of the benzene rings."<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.legislation.govt.nz/act/public/1975/0116/latest/DLM436723.html | work = New Zealand Misuse of Drugs Act 1975 | title = Schedule 3 Class C Controlled Drugs; Part 7: Fentanyl analogues }}</ref>
A more recent and somewhat broader example was introduced into US Federal legislation in 2018, covering the following structures;
"...fentanyl-related substances includes any substance not otherwise controlled in any schedule...that is structurally related to fentanyl by one or more of the following modifications:
# Replacement of the phenyl portion of the phenethyl group by any monocycle, whether or not further substituted in or on the monocycle; # substitution in or on the phenethyl group with alkyl, alkenyl, alkoxyl, hydroxyl, halo, haloalkyl, amino or nitro groups; # substitution in or on the piperidine ring with alkyl, alkenyl, alkoxyl, ester, ether, hydroxyl, halo, haloalkyl, amino or nitro groups; # replacement of the aniline ring with any aromatic monocycle whether or not further substituted in or on the aromatic monocycle; and/or # replacement of the N-propionyl group by another acyl group."<ref>{{cite web | url = https://www.federalregister.gov/documents/2018/02/06/2018-02319/schedules-of-controlled-substances-temporary-placement-of-fentanyl-related-substances-in-schedule-i | work = United States Federal Register | title = Schedules of Controlled Substances: Temporary Placement of Fentanyl-Related Substances in Schedule I }}</ref>

revision.comment: /* Comparison */
The astronauts weren't completed in 1965 at a cost of $3.5M
revision.text:
{{Infobox NRHP | name =Lunar Landing Research Facility | nrhp_type = nhl | designated_other1 = Virginia Landmarks Register | designated_other1_date = February 18, 1986<ref name=register>{{cite web|title=Virginia Landmarks Register|url=http://www.dhr.virginia.gov/registers/register_counties_cities.htm|publisher=Virginia Department of Historic Resources|accessdate=19 March 2013}}</ref> | designated_other1_number = 114-0140 | designated_other1_num_position = bottom | image = Drop Test at Lunar Landing Research Facility - GPN-2000-001287.jpg | caption = The site as the Impact Dynamics Research Facility (1974) | location= [[Hampton, Virginia]] | coordinates = {{coord|37|6|8|N|76|23|23|W|display=inline,title}} | locmapin = Virginia#USA | area = | built =1965 | architect= NASA | architecture= | designated_nrhp_type= October 3, 1985<ref name="nhlsum">{{cite web|url=http://tps.cr.nps.gov/nhl/detail.cfm?ResourceId=1925&ResourceType=Structure|title=Lunar Landing Research Facility|accessdate=2008-06-26|work=National Historic Landmarks listing|publisher=National Park Service|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071229070511/http://tps.cr.nps.gov/nhl/detail.cfm?ResourceId=1925&ResourceType=Structure|archivedate=2007-12-29|df=}}</ref> | added = October 3, 1985<ref name="nris">{{NRISref|2008a}}</ref> | governing_body = [[NASA]] | refnum=85002808 }} The '''Lunar Landing Research Facility''' was an area at NASA's [[Langley Research Center]] in [[Hampton, Virginia]] that was used to simulate [[Apollo program|Apollo Moon landings]] with a mock [[Lunar Module]] powered by a small rocket motor suspended from a crane over a simulated lunar landscape.
Completed in 1965 at a cost of $3.5 million, the facility was used by 24 astronauts, including [[Neil Armstrong]] and [[Buzz Aldrin]], to practice solving piloting problems they would encounter in the last 150 feet of descent to the surface of the Moon.<ref name="crgis.ndc.nasa.gov">[http://crgis.ndc.nasa.gov/historic/1297 NASA Impact Dynamics Research Facility]</ref>
The structure was used to facilitate "flying" a full-scale Lunar Excursion Module Simulator (LEMS). The LEMS was suspended from a {{convert|200|ft|m|sing=on}}-tall, {{convert|400|ft|m|sing=on}}-long A-frame gantry by an overhead bridge crane. The LEMS is now on display at the [[Virginia Air and Space Center]].
==Post-Apollo uses==
Re-designated the '''Impact Dynamics Research Facility''' (IDRF) in 1974, the site was used for research on aircraft crashes until 2003. With limited funding for maintenance, NASA then closed the facility and it was listed for demolition.<ref name="crgis.ndc.nasa.gov"/>
In 2004, NASA determined that the IDRF could be adapted to support the Constellation program. It was re-opened in 2005 to conduct landing tests associated with the development of the Crew Exploration Vehicle (CEV) ''Orion''. The facility was renamed the '''Landing and Impact Research Facility''' (LandIR) and minor modifications were made, including a new parallel winch system to support full-scale ''Orion'' testing and a new hydro-impact basin (splashdown pool) below the gantry. Construction of the basin was completed in 2011. After Constellation was cancelled, the LandIR continued performing impact testing since the CEV will be used to service the [[International Space Station]].<ref name="crgis.ndc.nasa.gov"/>
The facility was designated a [[National Historic Landmark]] in 1985 for its role in the space program.
==See also== *[[List of National Historic Landmarks in Virginia]] *[[National Register of Historic Places listings in Hampton, Virginia]]

revision.text:
{{pp-semi|small=yes}} A '''motion picture content rating system''' is designated to [[Content rating|classify films]] with regard to suitability for audiences in terms of issues such as sex, violence, substance abuse, profanity, impudence or other types of mature content. A particular issued rating can be called a '''certification''', '''classification''', '''certificate''' or '''rating'''. Ratings typically carry age recommendations in an advisory or restrictive capacity, and are often given in lieu of [[censorship]]. In some jurisdictions the legal obligation of administering the rating may be imposed on [[movie theater]]s. In countries such as Australia and Singapore, an official government body decides on ratings; in other countries, such as the United States, it is done by industry committees with little if any official government status. In most countries, however, films that are considered morally offensive have been censored, restricted, or banned. Even if the film rating system has no legal consequences, and a film has not explicitly been restricted or banned, there are usually laws forbidding certain films, or forbidding minors to view them. The influence of specific factors in deciding a rating varies from country to country. In countries such as the United States, films with strong sexual content tend to be restricted to older viewers, though those same films are very often considered suitable for all ages in countries such as France and Germany. In contrast, films with violent content which would be rated leniently in the United States and Australia are often subject to high ratings and sometimes even censorship in countries such as Germany and Finland. Other factors may or may not influence the classification process, such as being set within a [[non-fictional]] historical context, whether the film glorifies violence or drug use, whether said violence or drug use is carried out by the protagonist, with whom the viewer should empathize, or by the antagonist. In Germany, for example, films depicting explicit war violence in a real war context (such as the Second World War) are handled more leniently than films with purely fictional settings. A film may be produced with a particular rating in mind. It may be [[Re-edited film|re-edited]] if the desired rating is not obtained, especially to avoid a higher rating than intended. A film may also be re-edited to produce an alternate version for other countries. {{horizontal TOC|limit=2|nonum=yes}} ==Comparison table== A comparison of current film rating systems, showing age on the horizontal axis. Note however that the specific ''criteria'' used in assigning a classification can vary widely from one country to another. Thus a color code or age range cannot be directly compared from one country to another. Key: *  '''White'''  – ''No restrictions: Suitable for all ages / Aimed at young audiences / Exempt / Not rated / No applicable rating''. *  '''Yellow'''  – ''No restrictions: Parental guidance is suggested for designated age range''. *  '''Purple'''  – ''No restrictions: Not recommended for a younger audience but not restricted''. *  '''Red'''  – ''Restricted: Parental accompaniment required for younger audiences''. *  '''Black'''  – ''Prohibitive: Exclusively for older audience / Restricted to licensed premises / Purchase age-restricted / Banned''. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ! Other |} ==Argentina== Through its Advisory Commission of Cinematographic Exhibition (''Comisión Asesora de Exhibición Cinematográfica'') the [[National Institute of Cinema and Audiovisual Arts]] (INCAA) issues ratings for films based on the following categories:{{cite web |title=Cinematographia – Decreto Nº 3.899 |trans-title=Decree No. 3,899 |date=14 December 1984 |language=Spanish |work=InfoLEG |publisher=[[Minister of Economy of Argentina]] |location=Buenos Aires |url=http://infoleg.mecon.gov.ar/infolegInternet/anexos/35000-39999/38308/norma.htm |accessdate=24 May 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140525195618/http://infoleg.mecon.gov.ar/infolegInternet/anexos/35000-39999/38308/norma.htm |archivedate=25 May 2014 |df= }} {{multiple image|caption_align=center|header_align=center |width = 50 | image1 = INCAA ATP.png | alt1 = ATP | image2 = INCAA +13.png | alt2 = +13 | image3 = INCAA +16.png | alt3 = +16 | image4 = INCAA +18.png | alt4 = +18 | image5 = INCAA C.png | alt5 = C | footer = Categories of the Argentinian classification system }} *'''ATP''': Suitable for all ages, ATP stands for "Apta (para) Todo Público", meaning "for all public" *'''+13''': Suitable for 13-year-olds and over. Children under the age of 13 are admitted if accompanied by an adult. *'''+16''': Suitable for 16-year-olds and over. *'''+18''': Suitable for 18-year-olds and over. *'''C''': Suitable for 18-year-olds and over. Restricted to specially licensed venues. ==Australia== {{Main article|Australian Classification Board}} The [[Australian Classification Board|Classification Board]] and [[Australian Classification Review Board|Classification Review Board]] are government-funded organizations which classify all films that are released for public exhibition.{{cite web |title=Information for Parents: Classification categories explained |publisher=Australian Classification Board |url=http://www.classification.gov.au/Public/Resources/Pages/Parents.aspx |accessdate=10 May 2015}}{{cite web |last=Clare |first=Jason (Minister for Justice) |title=Guidelines for the Classification of Films 2012 |date=10 December 2012 |publisher=Commonwealth of Australia |url=http://www.comlaw.gov.au/Details/F2012L02541 |accessdate=10 May 2015}} {{multiple image|perrow=3|caption_align=center|header_align=center |width = 50 | image1 = Australian OFLC G tag logo.svg | alt1 = G | image2 = PG classification tag from OFLC.svg | alt2 = PG | image3 = Australian OFLC M logo.svg | alt3 = M | image4 = MA 15+ classification tag from OFLC.svg | alt4 = MA15+ | image5 = OFLC small R18+.svg | alt5 = R18+ | image6 = OFLC X 18 classification tag.svg | alt6 = X18+ | footer = The Australian classifications }} * Advisory categories ** General ('''G''') – ''General''. The content is very mild in impact. The G classification is suitable for everyone. ** Parental Guidance ('''PG''') – ''Parental guidance recommended''. The content is mild in impact. It is not recommended for viewing or playing by persons under 15 without guidance from parents or guardians. ** Mature ('''M''') – ''Recommended for mature audiences''. The content is moderate in impact. Children under 15 may legally access this material because it is an advisory category. However, M classified films and computer games may include classifiable elements such as violence and nudity of moderate impact that are not recommended for children under 15 years. * Restricted categories ** Mature Accompanied ('''MA15+''') – ''Not suitable for people under 15. Under 15s must be accompanied by a parent or adult guardian''. The content is strong in impact. ** Restricted ('''R18+''') – ''Restricted to 18 years and over''. The content is high in impact. Despite this category being legally restricted, in Queensland the restriction is not applicable to persons under 2.{{Cite web |url=http://www.classification.gov.au/Industry/Journey/Documents/Resources/CLS%20-%20Cinema%20Managers%20Factsheet%20-%20December%2012%20update.pdf |title=CLS - Cinema Managers Factsheet - December 12 update |publisher=Australian Classification Board |location=Australia |language=English |format=PDF |publication-date=December 2012}} * Adult film categories ** Restricted ('''X18+''') – ''Restricted to 18 years and over''. This classification is a special and legally restricted category which contains only sexually explicit content. That is, material which shows actual sexual intercourse and other sexual activity between consenting adults. X18+ films are only available for sale or hire in the Australian Capital Territory and the Northern Territory. ** '''RC''' – ''Refused Classification''. Banned from sale or hire in Australia and cannot be legally imported. Films are rated RC if their content is very high in impact and exceeds the guidelines. Films intended to inform, educate or instruct or concerned with sport, religion or music are exempt from classification provided they do not contain material that would result in an "M" rating or higher if submitted for classification.{{cite web |title=Is it exempt? |publisher=Australian Classification Board |url=http://www.classification.gov.au/Industry/Journey/Pages/Exemptions/Step1.aspx |accessdate=10 May 2015}} ==Austria== Motion pictures are rated by the Austrian Board of Media Classification (ABMC) for the [[Federal Ministry of Education, Arts and Culture]] (Bundesministerium für Unterricht, Kunst und Kultur). The recommendations made by the ABMC are generally not legally binding and there are nine sets of state laws on the cinema sector with different age provisions.{{cite web |title=Austrian Board of Media Classification |publisher=[[Federal Ministry of Education, Arts and Culture]] |location=Vienna |url=http://www.bmukk.gv.at/medienpool/17350/abmc.pdf |format=PDF |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140528010006/http://www.bmukk.gv.at/medienpool/17350/abmc.pdf |archivedate=28 May 2014}} The only exception is in the case of "16" rated films, since under Austrian law there is a legal age restriction on certain types of content i.e. discrimination, sexual abuse, glorification of violence etc.{{cite web |title=Age Rating of Movies and Similar Image Carriers by the Austrian Youth Media Commission |work=Jugend Medien Kommission |publisher=[[Federal Ministry of Education, Arts and Culture]] |location=Vienna |url=http://www.bmukk.gv.at/medienpool/17349/jmk_agerating.pdf |format=PDF |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140528010429/http://www.bmukk.gv.at/medienpool/17349/jmk_agerating.pdf |archivedate=28 May 2014}} In addition to the ABMC's age recommendations, in the state of Vienna children under the age of 6 are only permitted to attend public film performances if they are accompanied.{{cite book |author=[[University of Oxford]] PCMLP |title=Study on Parental Control of Television Broadcasting |chapter=Annex 2: Comparative Analysis of Rating System – Cinema Rating Systems |year=1997 |publisher=[[European Commission]] |page=113 |url=http://ec.europa.eu/archives/information_society/avpolicy/docs/library/studies/finalised/parental_control/annexe2.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=28 June 2014}} The AMBC issues age recommendation from the following categories: *'''Unrestricted''' – Released for all age groups *'''6+''' – Released for children from age 6 *'''10+''' – Released for children from age 10 *'''12+''' – Released for children from age 12 *'''14+''' – Released from age 14 *'''16+''' – Released from age 16.
