revision.text:
{{Infobox spaceflight | name = Solar Anomalous and Magnetospheric Particle Explorer | names_list = Explorer-68, SMEX-1 | image = SAMPEX.jpg | image_caption = | image_size = 275px | mission_type = Magnetospheric research | operator = [[NASA]]{{\}}[[Goddard Space Flight Center|GSFC]]
[[Max Planck Institute for Extraterrestrial Physics|Max Planck Institute]] | COSPAR_ID = 1992-038A | SATCAT = 22012 | website = http://lasp.colorado.edu/sampex/sampex.html | mission_duration = Planned: 3 years
Final: {{Age in years, months and days|1992|07|03|2004|06|30}} | manufacturer = NASA{{\}}GSFC | launch_mass = {{convert|157|kg|lb|abbr=on}} | payload_mass = {{convert|45.2|kg|lb|abbr=on}} | dimensions = {{convert|1.5|xx|0.9|m|ft|abbr=on}} | power = 102 W | launch_date = {{start-date|July 3, 1992, 14:19|timezone=yes}} UTC | launch_rocket = [[Scout (rocket family)|Scout G-1]] | launch_site = [[Vandenberg Air Force Base|Vandenberg]] [[Vandenberg AFB Space Launch Complex 5|SLC-5W]] | entered_service = | disposal_type = Reentered | decay_date = {{end-date|November 13, 2012, 11:42|timezone=yes}} UTC | orbit_reference = [[Geocentric orbit|Geocentric]] | orbit_regime = [[Polar orbit|Near-polar]] | orbit_eccentricity = 0.009999999776482582 | orbit_periapsis = {{Convert|512|km|mi|abbr=on}} | orbit_apoapsis = {{convert|687|km|mi|abbr=on}} | orbit_inclination = 81.7° | orbit_period = 96.7 minutes | orbit_epoch = July 3, 1992 | apsis = gee | instruments_list = {{Infobox spaceflight/Instruments | acronym1 = HILT | name1 = Heavy Ion Large Telescope | acronym2 = LEICA | name2 = Low-Energy Ion Composition Analyzer | acronym3 = MAST | name3 = Mass Spectrometer Telescope | acronym4 = PET | name4 = Proton/Electron Telescope }} | programme = [[Small Explorer program]] | next_mission = [[Fast Auroral Snapshot Explorer|FAST]] }} The '''Solar Anomalous and Magnetospheric Particle Explorer''' ('''SAMPEX''') was a [[NASA]] solar and magnetospheric observatory, and was the first spacecraft in the [[Small Explorer program]]. It was launched into [[low Earth orbit]] on July 3, 1992, from [[Vandenberg Air Force Base]] aboard a [[Scout (rocket family)|Scout G-1]] rocket. SAMPEX was an international collaboration between NASA of the United States and the [[Max Planck Institute for Extraterrestrial Physics]] of Germany. The spacecraft carried four instruments designed to measure the anomalous components of [[cosmic ray]]s, emissions from [[solar energetic particles]], and electron counts in Earth's [[magnetosphere]]. Built for a three-year mission, its science mission was ended on June 30, 2004. Mission control for SAMPEX was handled by the [[Goddard Space Flight Center]] until October 1997, after which it was turned over to the [[Bowie State University]] Satellite Operations Control Center (BSOCC). BSOCC, with funding assistance from [[The Aerospace Corporation]], continued to operate the spacecraft after its science mission ended, using the spacecraft as an educational tool for its students while continuing to release science data to the public. Built for a three-year primary mission, the spacecraft continued to return science data until its [[atmospheric entry|reentry]] on November 13, 2012. ==Instruments== * Heavy [[Ion]] Large Telescope (HILT) * Low Energy Ion Composition Analyzer (LEICA) * [[Mass Spectrometer]] Telescope (MAST) measures the [[isotope|isotopic]] composition of elements from Li (Z=3) to Ni (Z=28) with energy from 10 to several hundred [[Electronvolt|MeV]]/[[nucleon]]. * [[Proton]]/[[Electron]] Telescope (PET) ==Collaborators== SAMPEX collaborators included: *[[The Aerospace Corporation]] **J. B. Blake, M. Looper, K. L. Lorentzen, D. Mabry, J. Mazur, R. Selesnick *[[California Institute of Technology]] ** A. Cummings, R. Leske, R. Mewaldt, E. Stone *[[Laboratory for Atmospheric and Space Physics]], [[University of Colorado Boulder]] **D. N. Baker, S. G. Kanekal, Xinlin Li *[[Max Planck Institute for Extraterrestrial Physics|Max Planck Institute]], Garching **D. Hovestadt, B. Klecker, M. Scholer *NASA [[Goddard Space Flight Center]] **T. Von Rosenvinge *NASA [[Langley Research Center]] **L. B. Callis, J. Lambeth *[[University of Maryland, College Park]] **G. M. Mason *[[Washington University in St. Louis]] **J. Cummings ==References== {{reflist |refs= {{cite web |url=http://www.srl.caltech.edu/sampex/DataCenter/ |title=SAMPEX Data Center |publisher=[[California Institute of Technology]] |accessdate=September 4, 2015}} {{cite web |url=https://directory.eoportal.org/web/eoportal/satellite-missions/s/sampex |title=SAMPEX |work=eoPortal |publisher=[[European Space Agency]] |accessdate=September 4, 2015}} {{cite web |url=http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/spacecraftOrbit.do?id=1992-038A |title=SAMPEX - Trajectory Details |work=[[National Space Science Data Center]] |publisher=NASA |accessdate=September 4, 2015}} {{cite conference |title=SAMPEX: NASA's first small explorer satellite |conference=IEEE Aerospace Conference. March 21–28, 1998. Aspen, Colorado. |first=G. M. |last=Mason |display-authors=etal |volume=5 |pages=389–412 |date=1998 |doi=10.1109/AERO.1998.685848 |bibcode=1998aero....5..389M}} {{cite news |url=http://www.aerospace.org/2012/11/21/sampex-mission-returns-to-earth/ |title=SAMPEX Mission Returns to Earth |publisher=[[The Aerospace Corporation]] |date=November 21, 2012 |accessdate=September 4, 2015}} {{cite news |url=http://www.nasa.gov/mission_pages/sunearth/news/sampex-deorbit.html |title=NASA's SAMPEX Mission: A Space Weather Warrior |publisher=NASA |first=Karen C. |last=Fox |date=November 1, 2012 |accessdate=September 4, 2015}} {{cite web |url=http://www.aerospace.org/cords/reentry-predictions/past-reentries-2012/1992-038a/ |title=Solar Anomalous and Magnetospheric Particle Explorer (SAMPEX) |publisher=The Aerospace Corporation |accessdate=September 4, 2015}} {{cite web |url=http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/experimentDisplay.do?id=1992-038A-02 |title=Heavy Ion Large Telescope (HILT) |work=National Space Science Data Center |publisher=NASA |accessdate=September 4, 2015}} {{cite web |url=http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/experimentDisplay.do?id=1992-038A-01 |title=Low-Energy Ion Composition Analyzer (LICA) |work=National Space Science Data Center |publisher=NASA |accessdate=September 4, 2015}} {{cite web |url=http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/experimentDisplay.do?id=1992-038A-03 |title=Mass Spectrometer Telescope (MAST) |work=National Space Science Data Center |publisher=NASA |accessdate=September 4, 2015}} {{cite web |url=http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/nmc/experimentDisplay.do?id=1992-038A-04 |title=Proton-Electron Telescope (PET) |work=National Space Science Data Center |publisher=NASA |accessdate=September 4, 2015}} }} ==Further reading== * {{cite journal |title=An overview of the Solar, Anomalous, and Magnetospheric Particle Explorer (SAMPEX) mission |journal=IEEE Transactions on Geoscience and Remote Sensing |first1=Daniel N. |last1=Baker |first2=Glenn M. |last2=Mason |first3=Orlando |last3=Figueroa |first4=G. |last4=Colon |first5=J. G. |last5=Watzin |first6=Roberto M. |last6=Aleman |display-authors=1 |volume=31 |issue=3 |pages=531–541 |date=May 1993 |doi=10.1109/36.225519 |bibcode=1993ITGRS..31..531B}} ==External links== {{Portal|Spaceflight}} *[http://lasp.colorado.edu/home/sampex/ SAMPEX website] by the University of Colorado Boulder *[http://www.srl.caltech.edu/sampex/DataCenter/ SAMPEX Data Center] by the California Institute of Technology *[https://web.archive.org/web/20121019164846/http://sunland.gsfc.nasa.gov/smex/sampex/index.html SAMPEX archived website] by the Goddard Space Flight Center {{Explorer program}} {{Orbital launches in 1992}} {{Use American English|date=January 2014}} [[Category:Spacecraft launched in 1992]] [[Category:Explorers program (NASA)]] [[Category:Space observatories]] [[Category:Space programme of Germany]] [[Category:Spacecraft which reentered in 2012]]

revision.comment: infobox
/* Overview */[[User:JCW-CleanerBot#Logic|task]], replaced: Publ. Astron. Soc. Japan → Publ. Astron. Soc. Jpn. using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox telescope |locmapin=USA Hawaii | wavelength = Optical/Infrared | built = Completed 1998 | diameter = 8.3 m<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cmog.org/telescopes/ |title=Corning Museum of Glass - Telescopes and Mirrors |publisher=Cmog.org |accessdate=2010-09-22}}</ref> (8.2 m usable) | diameter2 = 1330/1400/1265 mm<ref name=performance/> | angular_resolution = 0.23″<ref name=performance/> | focal_length = f/1.83 (15.000 m)<ref name=performance/> | mounting = [[Altazimuth mount|Altitude/Azimuth]] }} {{nihongo|'''Subaru Telescope'''|すばる望遠鏡|Subaru Bōenkyō}} is the {{convert|8.2|m|in|adj=on|sp=us}} flagship telescope of the [[National Astronomical Observatory of Japan]], located at the [[Mauna Kea Observatory]] on [[Hawaii (island)|Hawaii]]. It is named after the [[open star cluster]] known in English as the [[Pleiades]]. It had the largest monolithic [[primary mirror]] in the world from its commission until 2005.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://web-japan.org/kidsweb/hitech/subaru/index.html |title=The Subaru Telescope |publisher=web-japan.org |accessdate=2010-09-22}}</ref>
== Overview ==
The Subaru Telescope is a [[Ritchey-Chretien]] reflecting telescope. Instruments can be mounted at a [[Cassegrain reflector|Cassegrain]] focus below the primary mirror; at either of two [[Nasmyth telescope|Nasmyth]] focal points in enclosures on the sides of the telescope mount, to which light can be directed with a tertiary mirror; or at the [[prime focus]] in lieu of a secondary mirror, an arrangement rare on large telescopes, to provide a wide [[field of view]] suited to deep wide-field surveys.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.subarutelescope.org/Introduction/telescope.html |title=Specifications |publisher=Subaru Telescope" |accessdate=2010-09-22}}</ref>
In 1984, the [[University of Tokyo]] formed an engineering working group to develop and study the concept of a {{convert|7.5|m|in|adj=on|sp=us}} telescope. In 1985, the astronomy committee of Japan's science council gave top priority to the development of a "Japan National Large Telescope" (JNLT), and in 1986, the University of Tokyo signed an agreement with the [[University of Hawaii]] to build the telescope in Hawaii. In 1988, the National Astronomical Observatory of Japan was formed through a reorganization of the University's Tokyo Astronomical Observatory, to oversee the JNLT and other large national astronomy projects.<ref name=performance>{{Citation |url=http://optik2.mtk.nao.ac.jp/~iye/papers/iye208.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110722073446/http://optik2.mtk.nao.ac.jp/~iye/papers/iye208.pdf |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2011-07-22 |title=Current Performance and On-Going Improvements of the 8.2m Subaru Telescope |arxiv=astro-ph/0405012 |journal=Publ. Astron. Soc. Jpn. |volume=56 |issue=2 |pages=381–397 |date=2004-04-25 |bibcode=2004PASJ...56..381I |doi=10.1093/pasj/56.2.381 |last1=Iye |first1=M. |last2=Karoji |first2=H. |last3=Ando |first3=H. |last4=Kaifu |first4=N. |last5=Kodaira |first5=K. |last6=Aoki |first6=K. |last7=Aoki |first7=W. |last8=Chikada |first8=Y. |last9=Doi |first9=Y. |last10=Ebizuka |first10=N. |last11=Elms |first11=B. |last12=Fujihara |first12=G. |last13=Furusawa |first13=H. |last14=Fuse |first14=T. |last15=Gaessler |first15=W. |last16=Harasawa |first16=S. |last17=Hayano |first17=Y. |last18=Hayashi |first18=M. |last19=Hayashi |first19=S. |last20=Ichikawa |first20=S. |last21=Imanishi |first21=M. |last22=Ishida |first22=C. |last23=Kamata |first23=Y. |last24=Kanzawa |first24=T. |last25=Kashikawa |first25=N. |last26=Kawabata |first26=K. |last27=Kobayashi |first27=N. |last28=Komiyama |first28=Y. |last29=Kosugi |first29=G. |last30=Kurakami |first30=T. |display-authors=29 }}</ref>
Construction of the Subaru telescope began in April 1991, and later that year, a public contest gave the telescope its official name, "Subaru Telescope." Construction was completed in 1998, and the first scientific images were taken in January 1999.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.naoj.org/NAOJ/history.html |title=A Brief History of Subaru |publisher=Naoj.org |accessdate=2010-09-22}}</ref> In September 1999, [[Princess Sayako]] of Japan dedicated the telescope.<ref>{{cite web|last=French |first=Howard W. |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1999/09/19/world/on-hawaii-a-telescope-widens-orbit-of-japanese.html |title=On Hawaii, A Telescope Widens Orbit Of Japanese |location=Japan; Hawaii; Mount Mauna Kea (Hawaii) |publisher=Nytimes.com |date=1999-09-19 |accessdate=2010-09-22}}</ref>
A number of state-of-the-art technologies were worked into the telescope design. For example, 261 computer-controlled actuators press the main mirror from underneath, which corrects for primary mirror distortion caused by changes in the telescope orientation. The telescope enclosure building is also shaped to improve the quality of astronomical images by minimizing the effects caused by atmospheric turbulence.
Subaru is one of the few state-of-the-art telescopes to have ever been used with the naked eye. For the dedication, an eyepiece was constructed so that Princess Sayako could look through it directly. It was enjoyed by the staff for a few nights until it was replaced with the much more sensitive working instruments.<ref>{{Citation |url=http://ngm.nationalgeographic.com/print/2009/07/telescopes/ferris-text |title=Cosmic Vision |journal=National Geographic |date=July 2009 |first=Timothy |last=Ferris |accessdate=2009-09-13}}</ref>
Subaru is the primary tool in the search for [[Planet Nine]]. Its large field of view, 75 times that of the Keck telescopes, and strong light-gathering power are suited for deep wide-field sky surveys. The search, split between a research group led by Batygin and Brown and another led by Sheppard and Trujillo, is expected to take up to five years.<ref name="sciencemag201601">{{cite news|url=http://www.sciencemag.org/news/2016/01/feature-astronomers-say-neptune-sized-planet-lurks-unseen-solar-system|title=Astronomers say a Neptune-sized planet lurks beyond Pluto|last=Hand|first=Eric|date=20 January 2016|work=Science|accessdate=20 January 2016}}</ref>
=== Accidents during construction === Two separate incidents claimed the lives of four workers during the construction of the telescope. On October 13, 1993, 42-year-old Paul F. Lawrence was fatally injured when a forklift tipped over onto him. On January 16, 1996, sparks from a welder ignited insulation which smoldered, generating noxious smoke that killed Marvin Arruda, 52, Ricky Del Rosario, 38, and Warren K. "Kip" Kaleo, 36, and sent twenty-six other workers to the hospital in Hilo. All four workers are memorialized by a plaque outside the base of the telescope dome and a sign posted temporarily each January along the Mauna Kea access road.
===Mishap in 2011=== On July 2, 2011, the telescope operator in Hilo noted an anomaly from the top unit of the telescope.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.universetoday.com/87245/subaru-8-meter-telescope-damaged-by-leaking-coolant/|title=SUBARU 8-METER TELESCOPE DAMAGED BY LEAKING COOLANT|last=Atkinson|first=Nancy|date=24 December 2015|work=Universe Today|access-date=10 April 2017}}</ref> Upon further examination, coolant from the top unit was found to have leaked over the primary mirror and other parts of the telescope.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://subarutelescope.org/Announce/2011/07/04/report1.html |title=Serious Hardware Incident with the Subaru Telescope Interrupts Its Operation |publisher=web-subarutelescope.org/ |accessdate=2011-07-05}}</ref> Observation using Nasmyth foci resumed on July 22, and Cassegrain focus resumed on August 26.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://subarutelescope.org/Announce/2011/07/04/report4.html |title=Report 4: Resumption of Open Use Observations at Cassegrain Focus |date=September 13, 2011 |author=National Astronomical Observatory of Japan |accessdate=September 23, 2011}}</ref>
== Instruments == [[File:The Keck Subaru and Infrared obervatories.JPG|thumb|The Subaru alongside the twin [[W. M. Keck Observatory]] telescopes and the [[Infrared Telescope Facility]]]]
Several cameras and spectrographs can be mounted at Subaru Telescope's four focal points for observations in visible and infrared wavelengths.
; Multi-Object Infrared Camera and Spectrograph (MOIRCS) : Wide-field camera and spectrograph with the ability to take spectra of multiple objects simultaneously, mounts at the Cassegrain focus. ; Infrared Camera and Spectrograph (IRCS) : Used in conjunction with the new 188-element adaptive optics unit (AO188), mounted at the infrared Nasmyth focus. ; Cooled Mid Infrared Camera and Spectrometer (COMICS) : Mid-infrared camera and spectrometer with the ability to study cool interstellar dust, mounts on the Cassegrain focus. ; Faint Object Camera And Spectrograph (FOCAS) : Visible-light camera and spectrograph with the ability to take spectra of up to 100 objects simultaneously, mounts on the Cassegrain focus. ; Subaru Prime Focus Camera (Suprime-Cam) : 80-megapixel wide-field visible-light camera, mounts at the prime focus. Superseded by the Hyper Suprime-Cam in 2012, decommissioned in May 2017. ; High Dispersion Spectrograph (HDS) : Visible-light spectrograph mounted at the optical Nasmyth focus. ; Fiber Multi Object Spectrograph ([[FMOS]]) : Infrared spectrograph using movable fiber optics to take spectra of up to 400 objects simultaneously. Mounts at the prime focus. ; High-Contrast Coronographic Imager for Adaptive Optics (HiCIAO) : Infrared camera for hunting planets around other stars. Used with AO188, mounted at the infrared Nasmyth focus. ; Hyper Suprime-Cam (HSC) : This 900-megapixel ultra-wide-field (1.5° field of view) camera saw first light in 2012, and will be offered for open-use in 2014.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://subarutelescope.org/Observing/Instruments/HSC/index.html |title=HSC |publisher=Subaru Telescope, NAOJ |accessdate=December 27, 2013}}</ref> The extremely large wide-field correction optics (a seven-element lens with some elements up to a meter in diameter) was manufactured by Canon and delivered March 29, 2011.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://sumire.ipmu.jp/en/1648 | title=Subaru Telescope HSC Wide Field Corrector completed}}</ref> It will be used for surveys of weak lensing to determine dark matter distribution.<ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1117/2.3201407.17| title = Satoshi Miyazaki plenary: Hyper Suprime-Cam for Weak Gravitational Lensing Survey| journal = SPIE Newsroom| year = 2014 |url=http://spie.org/newsroom/as14_miyazaki}}</ref> ; Subaru Coronagraphic Extreme Adaptive Optics (SCExAO) : The Subaru Coronagraphic Extreme Adaptive Optics (SCExAO) instrument is a high-contrast imaging system for [[Direct imaging|directly imaging]] exoplanets.<ref>[http://www.naoj.org/Projects/SCEXAO SCExAO website]</ref> The [[coronagraph]] uses a [[Phase Induced Amplitude Apodization]] (PIAA) design which means it will be able to image planets closer to their stars than conventional [[Lyot type coronagraph]] designs. For example, at a distance of 100 pc, the PIAA coronagraph on SCExAO would be able to image from 4 AU outwards while [[Gemini Planet Imager]] and [[VLT-SPHERE]] from 12 AU outwards.<ref>Jovanovic, N., Martinache, F., Guyon, O., Clergeon, C., Singh, G., Kudo, T., Vievard, S., Newman, K., Minowa, Y., Hayano, Y., Kuhn, J., Serabyn, E., Norris, B., Tuthill, P., Stewart, P., Huby, E., Perrin, G., Lacour, S., Murakami, N., Fumika, O., 2014, [http://www.naoj.org/Projects/SCEXAO/06publis/06publis.html "SCExAO as a precursor to an ELT exoplanet direct imaging instrument"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140408221433/http://www.naoj.org/Projects/SCEXAO/06publis/06publis.html |date=2014-04-08 }},</ref> The system also has several other types of coronagraph: [[Vortex coronagraph|Vortex]], Four-Quadrant Phase Mask and 8-Octant Phase Mask versions, and a shaped pupil coronagraph.<ref>{{cite web|title=Overview|url=http://www.naoj.org/Projects/SCEXAO/index.html|website=SCExAO: The Subaru Coronagraphic Extreme AO Project|accessdate=21 August 2014}}</ref> The phase I of construction is complete<ref>[http://www.naoj.org/Projects/SCEXAO/02current_capabilities/02current_capabilities.html SCExAO Science ready Capabilities] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140408215613/http://www.naoj.org/Projects/SCEXAO/02current_capabilities/02current_capabilities.html |date=2014-04-08 }}</ref> and phase II construction to be complete by end of 2014<ref>[http://www.naoj.org/Projects/SCEXAO/03future_capabilities/03future_capabilities.html SCExAO Future Capabilities] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140408214909/http://www.naoj.org/Projects/SCEXAO/03future_capabilities/03future_capabilities.html |date=2014-04-08 }}</ref> for science operations in 2015. SCExAO will initially use the HiCIAO camera but this will be replaced by CHARIS,<ref>{{Cite journal|title=The Optical Design of CHARIS: An Exoplanet IFS for the Subaru Telescope|journal=Proceedings of SPIE, ()|volume=2013|pages=8864–58|arxiv=1309.3586|author1=Mary Anne Peters-Limbach|last2= Groff|first2=Tyler D.|last3= Jeremy Kasdin|first3=N.|last4=Driscoll|first4=Dave|last5=Galvin|first5=Michael|last6=Foster|first6=Allen|last7= Carr|first7=Michael A.|last8=LeClerc|first8=Dave|last9=Fagan|first9=Rad|last10= McElwain|first10=Michael W.|last11=Knapp|first11=Gillian|last12=Brandt|first12=Timothy|last13=Janson|first13=Markus|last14=Guyon|first14=Olivier|last15=Jovanovic|first15=Nemanja|last16=Martinache|first16=Frantz|last17=Hayashi|first17=Masahiko|last18=Takato|first18=Naruhisa|year=2013|bibcode = 2013SPIE.8864E..1NP |doi = 10.1117/12.2024070 }}</ref> an integral field spectrograph, around 2016.
== See also == {{comparison optical telescope primary mirrors.svg|220px}} * [[List of largest optical reflecting telescopes]]
== References == {{Reflist|35em}}
== External links == {{Commons category|Subaru Telescope}} * {{Official website|http://www.naoj.org}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20050624020730/http://www.nao.ac.jp/E/index.html National Astronomical Observatory of Japan] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20081120150822/http://www.nalux-world.com/subaru_e.htm Micro-lens for Subaru Telescope]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Subaru Telescope}} [[Category:Astronomical observatories in Hawaii]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Hawaii County, Hawaii]] [[Category:Exoplanet search projects]] [[Category:Telescopes]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta)
revision.text:
[[File:USS Tanager (AM-5).jpg|thumb|USS ''Tanager'' (AM-5)]]
The '''''Tanager''''' '''Expedition''' was a series of five [[biological survey]]s of the [[Northwestern Hawaiian Islands]] conducted in partnership between the [[Bureau of Biological Survey]] and the [[Bishop Museum]], with the assistance of the [[U.S. Navy]]. Four expeditions occurred from April to August 1923, and a fifth in July 1924. Led by [[Lieutenant commander (United States)|Lieutenant Commander]] [[Samuel Wilder King]] on the minesweeper {{USS|Tanager|AM-5}}, and [[Alexander Wetmore]] directing the team of scientists, the expedition studied the plant<ref>Christophersen & Caum 1931</ref> animal life, and [[geology]] of the central Pacific islands. Noted members of the team include archaeologist [[Kenneth Emory]] and [[Herpetology|herpetologist]] [[Chapman Grant]].
The expedition began with the goal of exterminating [[domestic rabbit]]s that had been introduced to [[Laysan]] island by the guano industry in 1902. Since that time, the rabbits had devoured Laysan's vegetation and led to the extinction of several endemic species. The rabbits were eventually eliminated on Laysan, and the crew witnessed the extinction of the [[Laysan honeycreeper]] ({{okina}}apapane). Throughout the expedition, new species were discovered and named, and unique specimens were captured and returned to laboratories for further study. Over 100 [[Archaeology|archaeological]] sites were found, including ancient religious sites and prehistoric settlements on [[Nihoa]] and [[Necker Island (Hawaii)|Necker Island]].
==First expedition== The first expedition departed Honolulu on April 4, 1923 and returned on May 4.<ref name="Thrum-91">Thrum 1923, p.92</ref> The team visited the island of [[Laysan]], [[Pearl and Hermes Atoll]], [[Midway Atoll]], and [[Kure Atoll]]. When they spent a month on [[Laysan]] studying the endemic [[Laysan honeycreeper]], a violent and sudden storm ravaged the island. After the storm, the crew concluded that the last three specimens of the honeycreeper had been killed.
[[File:Laysan Aerial.jpg|thumb|Laysan island]]
===Crew=== *[[Alexander Wetmore]] (assistant biologist) *Stanley C. Ball (biologist) *J. W. Thompson (Bishop Museum) *David T. Fullaway (entomologist) *David Thaanum (conchologist) *Edward L. Caum (botanist) *[[Donald Ryder Dickey]] (photographer) *Charles E. Reno (rodent control specialist) *John Baker *[[Chapman Grant]] (Ornithology assistant, herpetologist) *Eric Schlemmer (general utility)
==Second expedition== The second expedition departed Honolulu on May 10.<ref name="Thrum-91" /> The team visited the island of [[Laysan]], the [[French Frigate Shoals]] and the [[Pearl and Hermes Atoll]].
[[File:Starr 990615-0895 Coronopus didymus.jpg|thumb|Pearl and Hermes Atoll]]
===Crew=== *Alexander Wetmore (assistant biologist) *Stanley C. Ball (biologist) *J. W. Thompson (Bishop Museum) *David T. Fullaway (entomologist) *David Thaanum (conchologist) *Edward L. Caum (botanist) *[[Donald Ryder Dickey]] (photographer) *Charles E. Reno (rodent control specialist) *John Baker *[[Chapman Grant]] (Ornithology assistant, herpetologist) *Eric Schlemmer (general utility) *L. A. Thurston *Gerrit P. Wilder (botanist) *F. R. Lawrence *Ted. Dranga *Austin Jones
==Third expedition== The third expedition departed Honolulu on June 9.<ref name="Thrum-91" /> The team visited the islands of [[Necker Island (Northwestern Hawaiian Islands)|Necker]], [[Nihoa]], and the [[French Frigate Shoals]]. An attempt was also made to visit [[Kaʻula|Kaula]]. ''Tanager'' arrived at Nihoa on June 10 and dropped off scientists for a ten-day visit and moved on to Necker the following day to drop off a second team. Both teams used radio to keep in constant communication between the two islands.<ref>Evenhuis & Eldredge 2004, p.47</ref> On Nihoa, botanist Edward Leonard Caum collected the first specimen of ''[[Amaranthus brownii]]'' and Alexander Wetmore discovered the [[Nihoa millerbird]] and named it ''Acrocephalus familiaris kingi'', in honor of Captain [[Samuel Wilder King]].<ref>Rauzon 2001, p.18</ref> Evidence of an ancient settlement on Nihoa was discovered, along with platforms, terraces, and human remains.<ref name="Emory">Emory 1928</ref>
On June 22, the ''Tanager'' arrived in the French Frigate Shoals and remained for six days, completing the first comprehensive survey of the atoll.<ref>Amerson 1971</ref> The expedition returned to Honolulu on July 1.<ref name="Thrum-91" />
[[File:Necker Island Standing Stones.jpg|thumb|Necker Island]]
===Crew=== *C. S. Judd ([[Cartography|cartographer]]) *C. M. Cooke (conchologist) *E. H. Bryan, Jr. (entomologist) *H. S. Palmer (geologist) *Edward Leonard Caum (botanist) *[[Kenneth Emory]] (archaeologist) *A. L. C. Atkinson *Bruce Cartwright *A. G. Rice *W. G. Anderson {{clear}}
==Fourth expedition== The fourth expedition consisted of two teams, with the first departing Honolulu on July 7.<ref name="Thrum-91" /> Destinations included [[Johnston Atoll]] and [[Wake Island]]. The first team left on the [[USS Whippoorwill (AM-35)|''Whippoorwill'' (AM-35)]], which made the first survey of [[Johnston Island]] in the 20th century. Aerial survey and mapping flights over Johnston were conducted with a [[Douglas DT]]-2 [[floatplane]] carried on her fantail, which was hoisted into the water for take off. Two destroyer convoys accompanied the expedition from Honolulu. The [[USS Tanager (AM-5)|''Tanager'' (AM-5)]] left Honolulu on July 16 and joined up with the ''Whippoorwill'' to complete the survey. From July 27 to August 5, the expedition surveyed Wake Island and named its islets: The southwest islet was named after [[Charles Wilkes]] who had led the [[United States Exploring Expedition]] in 1841 and determined the location of Wake Island. The northwest islet was named after [[Titian Peale]], the chief naturalist for the 1841 expedition.
[[File:Johnston-Atoll-DF-ST-92-02431.JPEG|thumb|Johnston Atoll]]
===Crew=== ;Whippoorwill *Alexander Wetmore (assistant biologist) *Charles Howard Edmonson (marine biologist) *Jas. B. Pollock (botanist) *E. H. Bryan, Jr. *W. G. Anderson *Max Schlemmer, Jr.
;Tanager *H. S. Palmer *David Thaanum (conchologist) *G. R. Mann (surveyor) *Orme Cheatham
==Fifth expedition== The fifth expedition visited Nihoa and [[Necker Island (Northwestern Hawaiian Islands)|Necker Island]] in 1924.<ref>Hīroa 1945, p.47</ref> Archaeologist [[Kenneth P. Emory]] of the Bishop Museum cleared out 60 sites on Nihoa and collected and cataloged artifacts.<ref name="Emory" /> The expedition visited Necker from July 14–17.
===Crew=== ''This list is incomplete'' [[File:Poacher's workshop, Peale Island, July 27, 1923.jpg|thumbnail|A poacher's workshop on Peale Island, part of [[Wake Island]], as taken by [[Alexander Wetmore]] during the expedition]] *Stanley C. Ball (biologist) *E. H. Bryan, Jr. *Edward L. Caum ([[Botany|botanist]]) *Erling Christophersen (botanist) *[[Donald Ryder Dickey]] (photographer) *[[Kenneth Emory]] ([[Archaeology|archaeologist]]) *David T. Fullaway (entomologist) *[[Chapman Grant]] (Ornithology assistant, [[Herpetology|herpetologist]]) *Herbert E. Gregory (Director, Bishop Museum) *C. S. Judd ([[Cartography|cartographer]]) *A. J. Ker *Commander Samuel W. King *Charles E. Reno (rodent control specialist) *Eric Schlemmer (general utility) *David Thaanum (conchologist) *J. W. Thompson (Bishop Museum) *[[Alexander Wetmore]] (assistant biologist) *Gerrit P. Wilder (botanist) *T. Wilson
==Repatriation== In 1990, the U.S. congress passed the [[Native American Graves Protection and Repatriation Act]] which requires federal agencies and institutions that receive federal funding to return Native American cultural items and human remains to their people. In the 1990s, '''Hui Mālama''' (Hui Mālama I Na Kūpuna O Hawai{{okina}}i Nei), a [[Native Hawaiian]] group, spent two years petitioning the [[United States Fish and Wildlife Service]] for the release of the bones (''iwi'') from seven Hawaiian skeletons originally taken from Nihoa and Necker Island by the Tanager Expedition in 1924. Although the bones were owned by the USFWS, the Bishop Museum acted as custodian.<ref>Rauzon 2001, pp.44-51</ref> The bones were finally released to the group, and in November, 1997, Hui Mālama chartered a yacht and travelled to Nihoa and Necker to [[Repatriation#Repatriation of human remains|rebury the remains]].<ref>Hawai'i Department of Land and Natural Resources 2008, p.12</ref>

revision.comment: [[Judith R. Goodstein]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox television | show_name = The Mechanical Universe | image = | caption = | creator = [[David Goodstein]] | genre = [[Educational television|Educational]] | developer = | starring = David Goodstein | narrated = Aaron Fletcher, Sally Beaty | theme_music_composer = Sharon Smith, Herb Jimmerson | opentheme = | endtheme = | country = {{USA}} | language = [[English Language|English]] | num_seasons = 1 | num_episodes = 52 | list_episodes = | executive_producer = Sally Beaty | producer = Peter Buffa | location = [[Pasadena, California]] | camera = Pat Allen | runtime = 30 minutes | network = [[Public Broadcasting Service|PBS]] | picture_format = [[NTSC]] | audio_format = | first_aired = 1985 | last_aired = 1986 | preceded_by = | followed_by = | related = ''[[Project Mathematics!]]'' | website = http://www.its.caltech.edu/~tmu/ }} '''''The Mechanical Universe'''''... ''And Beyond'' is a 52-part telecourse, filmed at the [[California Institute of Technology]], that introduces university level physics, covering topics from [[Copernicus]] to [[quantum mechanics]]. The series was produced by Caltech and INTELECOM, a nonprofit consortium of California [[community college]]s now known as [[Intelecom Learning]],{{Cite news|url=https://www.intelecom.org/our-story/|title=Our Story|work=Intelecom Learning|access-date=2017-06-22|language=en-US}} with financial support from [[Annenberg/CPB]]. == Overview == Produced starting in 1982, the videos make heavy use of historical dramatizations and visual aids to explain physics concepts. The latter were state of the art at the time, incorporating almost 8 hours of [[computer animation]] created by [[computer graphics]] pioneer [[Jim Blinn]].{{Cite book|url=https://ntrs.nasa.gov/archive/nasa/casi.ntrs.nasa.gov/19900013645.pdf|title=Pictorial Communication in Virtual and Real Environments|first=Jim|publisher=Taylor & Francis|year=1991|isbn=978-0-7484-0008-9|editor-last=Ellis|editor-first=Stephen R.|location=|pages=|chapter=The making of ''The Mechanical Universe''|postscript=|editor-last2=Kaiser|editor-first2=Mary K.|editor-last3=Grunwald|editor-first3=Arthur C.|author1=Blinn}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.fxguide.com/featured/founders-series-industry-legend-jim-blinn/|title=Founders Series: industry legend Jim Blinn|last=|first=|date=2012-07-24|work=[[fxguide]]|access-date=2017-07-28|language=en-US}} Each episode opens and closes with bookend segments in which Caltech professor [[David Goodstein]], speaking in a lecture hall, delivers explanations "that can't quite be put into the mouth of our affable, faceless narrator".{{Cite journal|last=Goodstein|first=David L.|last2=Olenick|first2=Richard P.|date=1988-09-01|title=Making ‘‘The Mechanical Universe’’|url=http://resolver.caltech.edu/CaltechAUTHORS:20151214-123255999|journal=American Journal of Physics|volume=56|issue=9|pages=779–785|doi=10.1119/1.15485|issn=0002-9505|via=|bibcode=1988AmJPh..56..779G}} After more than a quarter century, the series is still often used as a supplemental teaching aid, for its clear explanation of fundamental concepts such as [[special relativity]].{{Cite news|url=http://www.openculture.com/2017/05/the-pioneering-physics-tv-show-the-mechanical-universe-is-now-on-youtube-52-complete-episodes-from-caltech.html|title=The Pioneering Physics TV Show, The Mechanical Universe, Is Now on YouTube: 52 Complete Episodes from Caltech|work=Open Culture|access-date=2017-06-21|language=en-US}}{{Cite web|first=Meade|last=Brooks|year=2014|url=http://iws.collin.edu/mbrooks/documents/mechanical_universe/PHYS_1402_Physics_Videos.htm|title=PHYS-1402 Video Assignments|website=[[Collin College]]|access-date=2017-09-02}}
{{Cite web|url=http://physics.eou.edu/courses/phys_223/phys_223_lab1.pdf|title=PHYS 223 General Physics, Laboratory Session #1: Static Electricity|last=Tovar|first=Anthony A.|date=2013|website=[[Eastern Oregon University]]|access-date=2 September 2017}} The bookend segments featuring Goodstein were specially staged versions of actual freshman physics lectures from Caltech's courses Physics 1a and 1b. The organization and the choice of topics to emphasize in the television show reflect a then-recent revision of Caltech's introductory physics curriculum, the first total overhaul since the one represented by ''[[The Feynman Lectures on Physics]]'' almost two decades earlier. While Feynman generally sought contemporary examples of topics, the later revision of the curriculum brought a more historical focus:
In essence, the earlier Feynman course had sought to make physics exciting by relating each subject, wherever possible, to contemporary scientific problems. The new course took the opposite tack, of trying to recreate the historical excitement of the original discovery. For example, [[classical mechanics]]—a notoriously difficult and uninspiring subject for students—is treated as the discovery of "our place in the universe". Accordingly, [[celestial mechanics]] is the backbone of the subject and its climax is [[Isaac Newton|Newton]]'s solution of the [[Kepler problem]].
==Production details== The room seen in the bookend segments is the Bridge lecture hall at Caltech. Many of the extras were students from other schools, and the front rows of the lecture hall were deliberately filled with more women than would have typically been seen at Caltech lectures.{{Cite news|url=http://caltechcampuspubs.library.caltech.edu/1226/1/1983_09_30_85_2.pdf|title=A Mechanical Filming|last=Whang|first=Ken|date=30 September 1983|work=The California Tech|access-date=23 June 2017}} The TV production team added fake wood paneling to the lecture hall so that it would more closely resemble that seen in the show ''[[The Paper Chase (TV series)|The Paper Chase]]''. Later, the Caltech physics department was sufficiently impressed by the result that panels were installed permanently. Many seats in the lecture hall had to be removed in order to make room for the [[Camera dolly|camera track]] and studio lights. To cover this, additional reaction shots of a full lecture hall were filmed later, so that the illusion of a complete audience could be created in [[Film editing|editing]]. For most of the footage of Goodstein himself, only two rows of students were present.{{Cite news|url=http://calteches.library.caltech.edu/3397/1/Physics.pdf|title=Physics on the Tube|last=|first=|date=November 1983|work=Engineering & Science|access-date=23 June 2017}} Many other video segments were shot on location, for example at a [[The Linde Group|Linde]] industrial plant that produced [[liquid air]]. Historical scenes were often made to be generic, in order to facilitate their reuse across multiple episodes: "Young Newton strolls through an apple orchard, old Newton testily refuses a cup of tea from a servant, and so on". Footage featuring historical reenactment of [[Johannes Kepler]] was purchased from the [[Carl Sagan]] television series ''[[Cosmos: A Personal Voyage]]''. The series was originally planned to consist of 26 episodes.{{Cite news|url=http://caltechcampuspubs.library.caltech.edu/2413/1/1982_12_16_07.pdf|title=The Mechanical Universe: Caltech develops a physics course for educational television|last=|first=|date=December 1982|work=Caltech News|access-date=23 June 2017|issue=7|volume=16}}{{Cite journal|last=Gladstone|first=Daniel|date=1982|title=Caltech and Nebraska physicists produce college TV courses|url=http://physicstoday.scitation.org/doi/10.1063/1.2914889|journal=Physics Today|language=en|volume=35|pages=56|doi=10.1063/1.2914889|via=|bibcode=1982PhT....35l..56G}} This was later expanded to 60 episodes, a number then cut back to the eventual total of 52 for budget and production-schedule reasons.{{Cite news|url=|title=The new director of the Annenberg-Corporation for Public Broadcasting...|last=Shaw|first=Sydney|date=5 January 1984|work=UPI Archive: Washington News|access-date=|publisher=United Press International}} The show was intended not to require previous experience with [[calculus]]. Instead, the basics of [[Differential calculus|differential]] and [[integral calculus]] would both be taught early in the series itself. Caltech mathematician [[Tom M. Apostol]] joined the ''Mechanical Universe'' production staff in order to ensure that the series did not compromise on the quality of the mathematics it presented. Seeing an example of Blinn's computer animation for the first time convinced Apostol that the series could bring mathematics "to life in a way that cannot be done in a textbook or at the chalkboard".{{Cite journal|last=Albers|first=Donald J.|last2=Apostol|first2=Tom|date=1997|title=An Interview with Tom Apostol|jstor=2687147|journal=The College Mathematics Journal|volume=28|issue=4|pages=250–270|doi=10.2307/2687147}} When test screenings to [[humanities]] students revealed that their greatest difficulty learning calculus was a weak background in [[trigonometry]], Apostol wrote a primer on the subject to be distributed with the telecourse. After advising the production of ''The Mechanical Universe'', Apostol decided that a similar series, geared to high-school mathematics, would be beneficial.{{Cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1993-10-07/news/gl-42969_1_animated-computer-graphics|title=Animated Computer Graphics Give a New Angle to Math Education|last=Rollins|first=Bill|date=1993-10-07|work=Los Angeles Times|access-date=2017-06-22|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035}} This became the later Caltech series ''[[Project Mathematics!]]'', which also featured computer animation by Blinn. Some of Blinn's animations for ''The Mechanical Universe'' were reused in the new series, in order to illustrate applications of algebra, geometry, and trigonometry.See, for example, the ''[[Project Mathematics!]]'' episode "Sines and Cosines, Part 1", [https://www.youtube.com/watch?t=25m5s&v=9wh7xYMXKJ8 25:05 and following]. (Accessed 2018-01-28.) The science-fiction action movie [[Total Recall (1990 film)|''Total Recall'']] (1990) used portions of the ''Mechanical Universe'' title sequence, in a scene where the protagonist (Douglas Quaid, played by [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]]) is offered virtual vacations in locales around the [[Solar System]]. The animation was used without licensing, and consequently, Caltech and Intelecom sued [[Carolco Pictures]] for [[United States dollar|$]]3 million.{{Cite news|url=|title=Schools sue Carolco over 'Recall'|last=|first=|date=3 September 1992|work=[[Daily Variety]]|access-date=|page=12}} In order to present detailed mathematical equation derivations, the show employed a technique its creators called the "algebraic ballet". Computer animation presented derivations in step-by-step detail, but rapidly and with touches of whimsy, such as algebraic terms being canceled by a [[Monty Python]]-esque stomping foot or [[Michelangelo]]'s [[The Creation of Adam|Hand of God]]. Blinn felt that ''Cosmos'' had taken itself "too seriously", and so he aimed to include more humor in the ''Mechanical Universe'' animations.{{Cite news|url=http://articles.latimes.com/1987-01-09/entertainment/ca-2683_1_computer-animation|title=Computer Animation And Physics : Explaining Universe With Cartoons|last=Solomon|first=Charles|date=1987-01-09|work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|access-date=2018-01-12|language=en-US|issn=0458-3035}} The goal was to avoid putting the viewers' "brains into a [[Mains hum|60-cycle hum]]", without sacrificing rigor; the creators intended that students could learn the overall gist of each derivation from the animation, and then study the details using the accompanying textbook. Computer animation was also used to portray idealizations of physical systems, like simulated [[billiard ball]]s illustrating Newton's laws of motion. (Blinn had used some of the same software earlier to visualize the interaction of [[DNA]] and [[DNA polymerase]] for ''Cosmos''.{{Cite journal|last=Holzman|first=Robert E.|date=1986-07-01|title=Atoms to astronomy: Computer graphics at the Jet Propulsion Laboratory|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/BF01900326|journal=The Visual Computer|language=en|volume=2|issue=3|pages=159–163|doi=10.1007/BF01900326|issn=0178-2789}}) One commenter deemed these animations "particularly useful in providing students with subjective insights into dynamic three-dimensional phenomena such as [[magnetic field]]s".{{Cite journal|last=Ellis|first=S.R.|title=Nature and origins of virtual environments: a bibliographical essay|url=https://doi.org/10.1016/0956-0521(91)90001-L|journal=Computing Systems in Engineering|volume=2|issue=4|pages=321–347|doi=10.1016/0956-0521(91)90001-l}} Creating the computer graphics necessary to visualize physics concepts led Blinn to invent new techniques for simulating clouds, as well as the virtual "blobby objects" known as [[metaballs]].{{Cite web|url=https://osu.pb.unizin.org/graphicshistory/chapter/4-5-jpl-and-national-research-council-of-canada/|title=4.6 JPL and National Research Council of Canada {{!}} Computer Graphics and Computer Animation: A Retrospective Overview|last=Carlson|first=Wayne E.|date=2017-06-20|website=[[Ohio State University]]|access-date=2018-01-12}} Blinn used the vertex coordinates of [[Regular icosahedron|regular icosahedra]] and [[Regular dodecahedron|dodecahedra]] to determine the placement of [[electric field]] lines radiating away from point charges.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KBDS6GAwSwAC|title=Jim Blinn's Corner: A Trip Down the Graphics Pipeline|last=Blinn|first=Jim|date=1996|publisher=Morgan Kaufmann|year=|isbn=9781558603875|location=|pages=44|language=en}} Most of the narration was voiced by actor Aaron Fletcher, who also played [[Galileo Galilei]] in the historical segments. Some portions, such as explanations of particular technical details, were narrated by Sally Beaty, the show's [[executive producer]]. Shorter versions of ''Mechanical Universe'' episodes, 10 to 20 minutes in length, were created for use in [[Secondary school|high schools]]. This adaptation, for which a dozen high-school teachers and administrators were consultants, was supported by a $650,000 grant from the [[National Science Foundation]].{{Cite journal|last=Sweet|first=William|date=1984|title=Foundations award new grants for video science productions|url=http://physicstoday.scitation.org/doi/10.1063/1.2916409|journal=Physics Today|language=en|volume=37|pages=72|doi=10.1063/1.2916409|via=|bibcode=1984PhT....37R..72S}} These videos were distributed alongside supplemental written material for teachers' benefit, and were intended to be employed in conjunction with existing textbooks.{{Cite journal|last=Olenick|first=Richard P.|date=2016-12-02|title=The Development of Video Tapes for High School Physics Courses: The Mechanical Universe and beyond|url=https://doi.org/10.2190/WM1G-31MG-N9HA-YP38|journal=Journal of Educational Technology Systems|language=en|volume=17|issue=1|pages=33–46|doi=10.2190/wm1g-31mg-n9ha-yp38}} [[Yorkshire Television]] later produced a version repackaged for the United Kingdom audience, which was released in April 1991.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?hl=en&lr=&id=MREiAwAAQBAJ|title=Teaching Large Classes in Higher Education: How to Maintain Quality with Reduced Resources|last=Graham|first=Gibbs|last2=Alan|first2=Jenkins|date=2014-03-18|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781135350420|language=en}} ==Critical reception== ===Initial responses=== PBS and [[The Learning Channel]] began broadcasting ''The Mechanical Universe'' in September 1985.{{Cite journal|last=|first=|date=1985|title=Caltech's Television Physics Course Starts to Air This Month|url=http://physicstoday.scitation.org/doi/10.1063/1.2814699|journal=Physics Today|language=en|volume=38|pages=71|doi=10.1063/1.2814699|via=|bibcode=1985PhT....38S..71.}} During the fall of 1986, roughly 100 PBS stations carried ''The Mechanical Universe,'' and by the fall of 1987, over 600 higher-education institutions had purchased it or licensed the episodes for use. In 1992, Goodstein noted that the series had been broadcast, via PBS, by over 100 stations, "usually at peculiar hours when innocent people were unlikely to tune in accidentally on a [[differential equation]] in the act of being solved".{{Cite journal|last=Goodstein|first=David|date=1992-09-01|title=The science literacy gap: A Karplus lecture|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/BF00701360|journal=Journal of Science Education and Technology|language=en|volume=1|issue=3|pages=149–155|doi=10.1007/BF00701360|issn=1059-0145|bibcode=1992JSEdT...1..149G}} He observed that detailed viewership figures were difficult to obtain, but when the show had been broadcast in [[Miami]] during Saturday mornings, the producers were able to obtain [[Nielsen ratings]].
In fact, it came in second in its time slot, beating the [[Saturday-morning cartoon|kiddie cartoons]] on two network stations. There were 18,000 faithful core households in [[Miami-Dade County, Florida|Dade County]] alone, the median age of the viewers was 18, and half were female. However, we seldom get that kind of detailed information.
Goodstein and assistant project director Richard Olenick noted,
Anecdotal information in the form of letters and phone calls indicates very considerable enthusiasm among users at all levels from casual viewers to high-school students to research university professors, but there have also been a number of sharp disappointments, particularly when [[Instructional Television Fixed Service|Instructional Television]] administrators have tried to handle TMU like a conventional telecourse.
Similarly, a 1988 review in ''[[Physics Today]]'' suggested that the programs would not function well on their own as a telecourse, but would work much better as a supplement to a traditional classroom or a more standard distance-learning course such as [[Open University]].{{Cite journal|last=Kirkpatrick|first=Larry D.|last2=Wheeler|first2=Gerald F.|date=1988|title=The Mechanical Universe Telecourse|url=http://physicstoday.scitation.org/doi/10.1063/1.2811531|journal=Physics Today|language=en|volume=41|pages=74|bibcode=1988PhT....41h..74K|doi=10.1063/1.2811531|via=}} The reviewers also found the "algebraic ballet" of computer-animated equations too fast to follow: "After a short time, one yearns for a live professor filling the blackboard with equations". Similarly, a review in the ''[[American Journal of Physics]]'', while praising the "technical proficiency of the films", wrote of the animated equation manipulations, "As the [[MIT]] students say, this is like trying to take a drink of water out of a fire hose".{{Cite journal|last=Olenick|first=Richard P.|last2=Apostol|first2=Tom M.|last3=Goodstein|first3=David L.|last4=Arons|first4=A. B.|date=1986-09-01|title=The Mechanical Universe: Introduction to Mechanics and Heat|url=http://aapt.scitation.org/doi/10.1119/1.14420|journal=American Journal of Physics|volume=54|issue=9|pages=857–862|doi=10.1119/1.14420|issn=0002-9505|bibcode=1986AmJPh..54..857O}} A considerably more enthusiastic evaluation came from physicist [[Charles H. Holbrow]], who told Olenick, "These materials will constitute the principal visual image of physics for decades". Goodstein and Olenick reported that younger viewers tended to enjoy the "algebraic ballet" style "much more than older viewers, who are made uncomfortable by the algebraic manipulations they cannot quite follow". ===Classroom use=== In 1986, ''The Mechanical Universe'' was used as part of a summer program for [[gifted children]], to overall success.{{Cite journal|last=Tkach|first=John R.|date=1987|title=A Perennial Problem for Parents: What to Do with a Gifted Kid This Summer II|url=http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/10.1177/107621758701000302|journal=Gifted Child Today Magazine|language=en|volume=10|issue=3|pages=6–8|doi=10.1177/107621758701000302|via=}} A 1987 study at [[Indiana University Bloomington]] used 14 ''Mechanical Universe'' episodes as part of an introductory course on Newtonian mechanics, with generally positive results:
[T]hese tapes were particularly effective in placing Newtonian mechanics in a historical perspective; dramatizing the historical overthrow of [[Aristotelian physics|Aristotelian]] and medieval ideas; illustrating the diverse nature of scientists and the scientific endeavor; stimulating student interest and enthusiasm; and, through excellent animation, illustrating the time dimension of certain mechanics concepts. The companion text [...] was placed on library reserve for the course but was not extensively utilized by students.{{Cite journal|last=Hake|first=R. R.|date=1987-10-01|title=Promoting student crossover to the Newtonian world|url=http://aapt.scitation.org/doi/10.1119/1.14945|journal=American Journal of Physics|volume=55|issue=10|pages=878–884|doi=10.1119/1.14945|issn=0002-9505|bibcode=1987AmJPh..55..878H}}
A follow-up study found that the videos could also be helpful explaining physics to professors in other fields. Negative reactions generally had less to do with the intrinsic perceived quality of the episodes than with the time the science-history material took away from content seen as "critical exam-preparing instruction".{{Cite journal|last=Tobias|first=Sheila|last2=Hake|first2=R. R.|date=1988-09-01|title=Professors as physics students: What can they teach us?|url=http://aapt.scitation.org/doi/10.1119/1.15486|journal=American Journal of Physics|volume=56|issue=9|pages=786–794|doi=10.1119/1.15486|issn=0002-9505|bibcode=1988AmJPh..56..786T}} The investigator recalled,
[S]ome students, thinking that the videotape material would not be covered on the tests, headed for the doors when the lights dimmed! To counter this tendency I started to use a few test questions based on historical or literary details discussed in the videotapes. Some students were outraged: "What is this, a poetry class?"{{Cite journal|last=Hake|first=Richard|date=2011-12-27|title=Helping Students to Think Like Scientists in Socratic Dialogue-Inducing Labs|url=http://www.physics.indiana.edu/~hake/HelpStudThink-L.pdf|journal=The Physics Teacher|volume=50|issue=1|pages=48–52|doi=10.1119/1.3670087|issn=0031-921X|via=|bibcode=2012PhTea..50...48H}}
Classroom use continued into the 1990s. A minority education program at the [[University of California, Berkeley]] employed ''Mechanical Universe'' episode segments (on [[LaserDisc]]) as part of group discussions.{{Cite journal|last=Linn|first=Marcia C.|date=1996-11-01|title=Cognition and distance learning|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/(SICI)1097-4571(199611)47:113.0.CO;2-4/abstract|journal=[[Journal of the American Society for Information Science]]|language=en|volume=47|issue=11|pages=826–842|doi=10.1002/(sici)1097-4571(199611)47:11%3C826::aid-asi6%3E3.3.co;2-n|issn=1097-4571|via=}} In a 1993 review of the series, a science historian stated that he had used episodes in his classes for several years, naming "Kepler's Three Laws" and "The Michelson–Morley Experiment" as his personal favorites.
The highlight of the Kepler film is a segment in which we are shown an exquisite graphical realization of the way in which Kepler actually figured out that the orbits of the planets are elliptical rather than circular. The sheer difficulty of the problem he faced and the elegance of the method he applied to solve it are abundantly clear. I cannot imagine a better way to present this magnificent discovery, which can easily appear so trivial.{{Cite journal|last=Davis|first=Edward B.|date=1993|title=Review of "The Mechanical Universe"; "The Mechanical Universe and beyond"|jstor=235109|journal=[[Isis (journal)|Isis]]|volume=84|issue=4|pages=755–756|via=}}
A 2005 column in ''[[The Physics Teacher]]'' suggested ''The Mechanical Universe'' as preparatory viewing for instructors attempting to teach physics for the first time.{{Cite journal|last=Legleiter|first=Earl|date=2005-02-23|title=Advice from an Out-of-Field Physics Teacher|url=http://aapt.scitation.org/doi/10.1119/1.1869440|journal=The Physics Teacher|volume=43|issue=3|pages=188–189|doi=10.1119/1.1869440|issn=0031-921X|bibcode=2005PhTea..43..188L}} ''The Physics Teacher'' has also recommended the series "as enrichment or a makeup assignment for high-ability students".{{Cite journal|last=MacIsaac|first=Dan|date=2004-11-09|title=Web Resources for Teaching Rotational Motion and Thermal Physics: The Mechanical Universe|url=|journal=The Physics Teacher|volume=42|issue=9|pages=560–560|doi=10.1119/1.1828735|issn=0031-921X|via=|bibcode=2004PhTea..42Q.560M}} Writing for ''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]'' magazine's web site, [[Rhett Allain]] cited the series as an example of videos that could replace some functions of traditional lectures.{{cite web|last1=Allain|first1=Rhett|title=The Traditional Lecture Is Dead. I Would Know—I'm a Professor|url=https://www.wired.com/2017/05/the-mechanical-universe/|website=Wired|accessdate=28 July 2017|date=11 May 2017}} ==Awards== In 1987, "The Lorentz Transformation" (episode 42) was awarded the sixteenth annual [[Japan Prize (NHK)|Japan Prize]] for educational television.{{Cite web|url=http://www.nhk.or.jp/jp-prize/english/about/grandprix_winners.html|title=JAPAN PRIZE International Contest For Educational Media|website=www.nhk.or.jp|access-date=2017-06-22}} Other awards received by ''The Mechanical Universe'' include the 1986 Gold Award from the Birmingham International Film Festival, two "Cindy" awards from the International Association of Audio Visual Communicators (1987 and 1988), a Gold Award (1985) and a Silver Award (1987) from the International Film and TV Festival of New York, Silver (1986) and Gold Apple (1987) awards from the National Educational Film and Video Festival, and a Gold Plaque (1985) from the Chicago International Film Festival.{{Cite web|url=https://www.learner.org/catalog/awards/mucomments.html|title=The Mechanical Universe -- Views, Reviews and Awards|website=www.learner.org|access-date=2017-07-26}}{{Cite news|url=http://caltechcampuspubs.library.caltech.edu/2410/1/1986_02_20_01.pdf|title="Mechanical Universe" wins two awards|last=|first=|date=February 1986|work=Caltech News|access-date=30 July 2017}} Goodstein received the 1999 [[Oersted Medal]] for his work in physics education, including ''The Mechanical Universe''.{{Cite journal|last=Edge|first=Ronald D.|date=1999-02-17|title=American Association of Physics Teachers 1999 Oersted Medalist: David Goodstein|url=http://aapt.scitation.org/doi/10.1119/1.19223|journal=American Journal of Physics|volume=67|issue=3|pages=182–182|doi=10.1119/1.19223|issn=0002-9505|bibcode=1999AmJPh..67..182E}} For his contributions to the field of computer graphics, including his animations for ''Cosmos'', ''The Mechanical Universe'' and ''Project Mathematics!'', Blinn received a [[MacArthur Fellows Program|MacArthur fellowship]] in 1991, as well as the 1999 [[Steven A. Coons Award]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.macfound.org/fellows/422/|title=James F. Blinn: Computer Graphics Animator|last=|first=|date=|website=MacArthur Foundation|language=en|access-date=2018-01-12}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.siggraph.org/participate/awards/1999-coons-award|title=1999 Steven A. Coons Award: James F. Blinn|last=|first=|date=2015-01-04|work=[[ACM SIGGRAPH]]|access-date=2018-01-12|language=en}} == Portrayal of Tacoma Narrows Bridge collapse == {{Main|Tacoma Narrows Bridge (1940)}} Like many introductory physics texts, ''The Mechanical Universe'' cites the spectacular 1940 collapse of the [[Tacoma Narrows Bridge (1940)|Tacoma Narrows Bridge]] as an example of [[resonance]], using footage of the disaster in the "Resonance" episode. However, as more-recent expositions have emphasized, the catastrophic oscillations that destroyed the bridge were not due to simple mechanical resonance, but to a more complicated interaction between the bridge and the winds passing through it—a phenomenon known as [[Aeroelasticity#Flutter|aeroelastic flutter]]. This phenomenon is a kind of "self-sustaining vibration" that lies beyond the regime of applicability of the [[Linear differential equation|linear theory]] of the externally-driven [[Simple harmonic motion|simple harmonic oscillator]].{{Cite journal|last=Billah|first=K. Yusuf|last2=Scanlan|first2=Robert H.|date=1991-02-01|title=Resonance, Tacoma Narrows bridge failure, and undergraduate physics textbooks|url=http://www.ketchum.org/billah/Billah-Scanlan.pdf|journal=American Journal of Physics|volume=59|issue=2|pages=118–124|doi=10.1119/1.16590|issn=0002-9505|via=|bibcode=1991AmJPh..59..118B}}{{Cite journal|last=Olson|first=Donald W.|last2=Wolf|first2=Steven F.|last3=Hook|first3=Joseph M.|date=2015-10-31|title=The Tacoma Narrows Bridge collapse|url=http://physicstoday.scitation.org/doi/10.1063/PT.3.2991|journal=Physics Today|volume=68|issue=11|pages=64–65|doi=10.1063/PT.3.2991|issn=0031-9228|bibcode=2015PhT....68k..64O}} ==List of episodes== The opening sequence used for the first 26 episodes lists the show's title as ''The Mechanical Universe'', whereas the latter 26 episodes are titled ''The Mechanical Universe ...and Beyond''.{{Cite episode|title=Introduction|series=The Mechanical Universe|network=[[Public Broadcasting Service|PBS]]|season=1|number=1}}{{Cite web | url =http://www.learner.org/resources/series42.html | title =Resource: The Mechanical Universe...and Beyond | accessdate =28 May 2010 | year =2009 | publisher =Annenberg Media }} The reason for the addition is explained by Goodstein in the closing lecture segment of the final episode:
In the first scientific revolution, disputation over the interpretation of human or divine authority was replaced by observation, by measurement, by the testing of hypotheses, all of it with the powerful help of quantitative mathematical reasoning. And the result of all that was the mechanical universe, a universe that inexorably worked out its destiny according to precise, predictable, mechanical laws. Today, we no longer believe in that universe. If I know the precise position of some particle at some instant of time, I cannot have ''any idea'' of where it's going or how fast. And it doesn't make any difference at all if you say, "All right, you don't ''know'' where it's going, but where is it ''really'' going?" That is precisely the kind of question that is scientifically meaningless. That is the nature of the world we live in. That is the quantum mechanical universe."The Quantum Mechanical Universe" (episode 52), 25:37 and following.
The series can be purchased from Caltech or streamed from online video sources, including Caltech's official [[YouTube]] channel.{{Cite journal|last=MacIsaac|first=Dan|date=January 2017|title="The Mechanical Universe and Beyond" series now freely available on YouTube|url=|journal=[[The Physics Teacher]]|volume=55|pages=126|doi=10.1119/1.4974137|via=|bibcode=2017PhTea..55T.126.}} Caltech also posted on YouTube a series of short videos made by Blinn to demonstrate the show's computer animation at [[SIGGRAPH]] conferences. ===''The Mechanical Universe''=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="width:100%; margin:auto;" |- ! Rothschild |WrittenBy=Jack Arnold |Aux3=[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mFca4UwZB4I 35] |ShortSummary=Electric currents create, and are influenced by, magnetic fields, per the [[Biot–Savart law|Biot–Savart]] and [[Ampère's force law|Ampère]] laws. }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=36 |Title=[[Vector Field]]s and [[Hydrodynamics]] |DirectedBy=Robert Lattanzio |WrittenBy=Donald Button, Jack Arnold |Aux3=[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sB4C3YfSZyU 36] |ShortSummary=Some concepts apply generally to all vector fields and are useful both in electromagnetism and in the study of fluid flow. }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=37 |Title=Electromagnetic Induction |DirectedBy=uncredited |WrittenBy=Jack Arnold |Aux3=[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ygVZjQK5z-8 37] |ShortSummary=A changing magnetic field creates an electric current: [[electromagnetic induction]], demonstrated by Faraday in 1831. }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=38 |Title=[[Alternating Current]]s |DirectedBy=Mark Rothschild |WrittenBy=Jack Arnold |Aux3=[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=P-uyKrPlH9Q 38] |ShortSummary=In order to make the distribution of [[electric power]] practical over great distances, [[transformer]]s are used to change the voltages of [[alternating current]]s. }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=39 |Title=[[Maxwell's Equations]] |DirectedBy=Mark Rothschild |WrittenBy=Jack Arnold |Aux3=[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SS4tcajTsW8 39] |ShortSummary=By finding the missing conceptual piece in the mathematics of electricity and magnetism, [[James Clerk Maxwell|Maxwell]] discovers light is an [[electromagnetic wave]]. }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=40 |Title=[[Optics]] |DirectedBy=Robert Lattanzio |WrittenBy=Jack Arnold, David Goodstein |Aux3=[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=a-Nc5BhjOEU 40] |ShortSummary=Understanding light as a wave makes sense of [[reflection (physics)|reflection]], [[refraction]], and [[diffraction]]. }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=41 |Title=The [[Michelson–Morley experiment]] |DirectedBy=uncredited |WrittenBy=Don Bane |Aux3=[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ip_jdcA8fcw 41] |ShortSummary=If light is a wave, what is waving? By careful and precise measurement, Michelson and Morley tried to detect the Earth's motion through this medium, the "[[luminiferous aether]]", and found nothing. }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=42 |Title=The [[Lorentz Transformation]] |DirectedBy=uncredited |WrittenBy=Don Button |Aux3=[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=feBT0Anpg4A 42] |ShortSummary=Einstein realized that, if the speed of light is to be the same for all observers, then distances in space and durations of elapsed time must be relative. }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=43 |Title=Velocity and Time |DirectedBy=uncredited |WrittenBy=Jack Arnold, Richard Bellikoff |Aux3=[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BFLUa0ciMjw 43] |ShortSummary=Einstein arrived at the Lorentz transformation from a deeper conceptual understanding, creating a theory full of surprises like the [[twin paradox]]. }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=44 |Title=Energy, Momentum, and Mass |DirectedBy=uncredited |WrittenBy=Jack Arnold |Aux3=[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lZUrLq0LLIU 44] |ShortSummary=The [[conservation of momentum]] still applies in special relativity, but with new implications. }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=45 |Title=Temperature and the [[Gas Laws|Gas Law]] |DirectedBy=uncredited |WrittenBy=Jack Arnold |Aux3=[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=eZdUKMDfJ_o 45] |ShortSummary=The study of thermodynamics begins with gases. }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=46 |Title=The Engine of Nature |DirectedBy=Mark Rothschild |WrittenBy=Graham Berry, David Goodstein |Aux3=[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=d6eJ8mccvu0 46] |ShortSummary=An introduction to the [[Carnot engine]], an idealized machine for converting thermal energy into mechanical work. }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=47 |Title=Entropy |DirectedBy=uncredited |WrittenBy=David Goodstein, Jack Arnold |Aux3=[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ufI4TXaevlo 47] |ShortSummary=Further investigation of Carnot engines leads to the concept of [[entropy]]. }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=48 |Title=Low Temperatures |DirectedBy=uncredited |WrittenBy=[[Judith R. Goodstein]] |Aux3=[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3yqOdyfq6cU 48] |ShortSummary=Faraday makes [[chlorine]] gas into a liquid, kicking off the pursuit of [[cryogenics|lower and lower temperatures]], culminating in the liquification of [[helium]]. }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=49 |Title=The Atom |DirectedBy=uncredited |WrittenBy=David Goodstein, Jack Arnold |Aux3=[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ca10Sz1lPFE 49] |ShortSummary=The ancient Greeks introduced the notion that matter is made of [[atom]]s. In the early 20th century, [[spectral lines]] and the discovery of the [[atomic nucleus]] forced the development of new ideas. }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=50 |Title=Particles and Waves |DirectedBy=uncredited |WrittenBy=Donald Button |Aux3=[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=STJbtg-p4EA 50] |ShortSummary=Light, which had been thought to be a wave, was found to act in some circumstances like a stream of particles. This puzzle led to [[quantum mechanics]]. }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=51 |Title=Atoms to Quarks |DirectedBy=uncredited |WrittenBy=Donald Button |Aux3=[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6IWhRffFRc8 51] |ShortSummary=Understanding the [[wavefunction]]s that can be assigned to the [[electron]] in a [[hydrogen]] atom illuminates the shape of the [[periodic table of the elements]]. }} {{Episode list |EpisodeNumber=52 |Title=The Quantum Mechanical Universe |DirectedBy=uncredited |WrittenBy=David Goodstein |Aux3=[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Tl-C1r3IabY 52] |ShortSummary=A review of the series. }} |} ==Funding== [[Annenberg/CPB]] provided the funding for the production of ''The Mechanical Universe''.{{Cite web | url =http://www.its.caltech.edu/%7Etmu/ | title =The Mechanical Universe | accessdate =22 May 2010 | publisher =California Institute of Technology }} The show was one of the first twelve projects funded by the initial $90 million pledge the Annenberg Foundation gave to the Corporation for Public Broadcasting in the early 1980s.{{Cite web|url=http://www.annenbergfoundation.org/about/about_show.htm?doc_id=966063|title=Annenberg Foundation {{!}} About the Foundation {{!}} A Strong History of Grantmaking|date=2010-01-09|access-date=2017-06-22|deadurl=bot: unknown|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100109013313/http://www.annenbergfoundation.org/about/about_show.htm?doc_id=966063|archivedate=2010-01-09|df=}} The total cost of the project was roughly $10 million. Funding to broadcast the show came from the following. *[[Alfred P. Sloan Foundation]] *[[National Science Foundation]] *[[United States Department of Energy]] *[[Kavli Foundation (United States)|The Kavli Foundation]] *George D. Smith Fund *[[Volkswagen of America]] *[[Corporation for Public Broadcasting]] *[[Public Broadcasting Service|Viewers Like You]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==Companion textbooks== *R.P. Olenick, T.M. Apostol, and D.L. Goodstein (1986). ''The Mechanical Universe: Introduction to Mechanics and Heat'' (Cambridge University Press). {{ISBN|0-521-30429-6}} *R.P. Olenick, T.M. Apostol, and D.L. Goodstein (1986). ''Beyond the Mechanical Universe: From Electricity to Modern Physics'' (Cambridge University Press). {{ISBN|0-521-30430-X}} == External links == *[http://www.its.caltech.edu/~tmu/ ''The Mechanical Universe'' website at Caltech] *[http://themechanicaluniverse.org Corrected mirror of the Caltech website] *{{IMDb title|id=0396993}} *[https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PL8_xPU5epJddRABXqJ5h5G0dk-XGtA5cZ ''The Mechanical Universe'' on YouTube] *[http://www.learner.org/resources/series42.html Episode descriptions from Annenberg Media] {{DEFAULTSORT:Mechanical Universe}} [[Category:Television series by the Annenberg Foundation]] [[Category:American documentary television series]] [[Category:1980s American television series]] [[Category:1985 American television series debuts]] [[Category:1986 American television series endings]] [[Category:PBS network shows]] [[Category:American educational television series]] [[Category:Science education television series]]

page.title: Urban planning in the United States

revision.comment: stub sort
revision.text:
'''Urban planning in the United States''' is practice of [[urban planning]] as it relates specifically to localities and urban centers in the United States.
==History==
===Early history===
In 1682, [[William Penn]] founded [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]], planning it as a city to serve as a port on the Delaware River and as a place for government. Hoping that Philadelphia would become more like an English rural town instead of a city, Penn laid out roads on a [[grid plan]] to keep houses and businesses spread far apart, with areas for gardens and orchards. The city's inhabitants did not follow Penn's plans, as they crowded by the Delaware River, the port, and subdivided and resold their lots.<ref>''Philadelphia: A 300-Year History'', pages 7, 14 – 16</ref> Before Penn left Philadelphia for the last time, he issued the Charter of 1701 establishing it as a city. It became an important trading center, poor at first, but with tolerable living conditions by the 1750s. [[Benjamin Franklin]], a leading citizen, helped improve city services and founded new ones, such as fire protection, a library, and one of the American colonies' first hospitals.
President [[George Washington]] appointed [[Pierre L'Enfant]] in 1791 to design the new capital city (later named [[Washington, D.C.|the City of Washington]]) under the supervision of three Commissioners, whom Washington had appointed to oversee the planning and development of the federal territory that would later become the [[History of Washington, D.C.|District of Columbia]].<ref name=Leach>{{cite web|url={{NRHP url|id=97000332}}|title=L'Enfant Plan of the City of Washington, District of Columbia|work=National Register of Historic Places Registration Form|publisher=[[United States Department of the Interior]]: [[National Park Service]]|first=Sara Amy|last=Leach|first2=Elizabeth|last2=Barthold|date=1994-07-20|accessdate=2012-01-08}}</ref> [[Thomas Jefferson]], who worked alongside President Washington in overseeing the plans for the capital, sent L'Enfant a letter outlining his task, which was to provide a drawing of suitable sites for the federal city and the public buildings. Though Jefferson had modest ideas for the Capital, L'Enfant saw the task as far more grandiose, believing he was not only locating the capital, but also devising the city plan and designing the buildings.<ref name="seale">{{cite book |last=Seale |first=William |title=The President's House, Volume 1 |publisher=White House Historical Association |year=1986 |pages=1–4}}</ref> Dismissed by the Washington D.C. commission, L'Enfant's plan would not be revived and implemented until 1902, as part of the [[McMillan Plan|McMillan Commission]]'s efforts to rebuild the city.<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/755061638|title=Planning and community development A guide for the 21st century|last=M.|first=Ward, Robert|date=2011|publisher=WW Norton & Co|isbn=9780393732924|oclc=755061638}}</ref>
In 1811, land for [[New York City|New York]]'s [[Central Park]] was acquired by the city through [[eminent domain]] and incorporated into the urban plan.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.khanacademy.org/humanities/art-americas/us-art-19c/us-19c-arch-sculp-photo/a/olmsted-and-vaux-central-park|title=Olmsted and Vaux, Central Park|last=|first=|date=|website=Khan Academy|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-05-24}}</ref> Residents of [[Seneca Village]], a settlement of free African Americans and German and Irish immigrants located on the future site of Central Park, were evicted by 1857.<ref name=":0" /> [[Frederick Law Olmsted]], with the help of [[Calvert Vaux]], developed a design for Central Park, which was entered into the open competition held by the city, and subsequently won.<ref name=":0" /> Their plan was then successfully implemented by the city, and was opened to the public in the winter of 1858.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ny.com/articles/centralpark.html|title=History of Central Park, New York|website=www.ny.com|language=en|access-date=2017-05-24}}</ref>
=== The twentieth century === In 1909, the first National Conference on City Planning was held in Washington D.C.<ref name=":02">{{Cite journal|last=Peterson|first=Jon A.|date=2009-03-27|title=The Birth of Organized City Planning in the United States, 1909–1910|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/01944360802608484|journal=Journal of the American Planning Association|volume=75|issue=2|pages=123–133|doi=10.1080/01944360802608484|issn=0194-4363}}</ref> Dominating the conference, Benjamin C. Marshall urged the government to conduct a 'civic census' to study the state of American cities, educate the public on its findings, and establish a national city-planning committee.<ref name=":02" />
[[Daniel Burnham]] was commissioned by the Chicago Merchants Association to lead a team to plan Chicago's [[World's Columbian Exposition]] of 1893.<ref name=":1" />
In 1933, the National Planning Board was established.<ref name=":1" />
In 1965, President Lyndon B. Johnson established the [[United States Department of Housing and Urban Development|Department of Housing and Urban Development]].<ref name=":1" />
==References== <references/>
==See also== ===Overviews and related topics=== * [[Urban planning]]
===Specific cities, towns, and urban centers=== * [[History of Philadelphia]] * [[Augusta, Georgia]] * [[New Haven, Connecticut]] * [[Holyoke, Massachusetts]] * [[Annapolis, Maryland]] * [[Charleston, South Carolina]] * [[Columbia, South Carolina]] * [[New Orleans]] * [[Mobile, Alabama]] * [[Pierre L'Enfant]]
[[Category:Urban planning in the United States| ]] {{planning-stub}}
